template.name: AWS_Website scenario with API engine and Database Management System in on-premises
template.desc:
Hybrid network connectivity from a data center to the AWS Cloud
Highly available and scalable cloud Domain Name System (DNS) web service Amazon Route 53, as well as Amazon API Gateway and Amazon Relational Database Service (Amazon RDS), allow many AWS customers to create web applications with separated data flow scenarios for regulated and unregulated workloads. Sensitive data can stored and processed in an on-premises data center, while other data stored and processed in Web application, hosted in the AWS Cloud.

trustZone.desc: All intranet subnets allocated to user campuses, with exception of DC LAN.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure comprehensive auditing and monitoring of all API calls and actions made through AWS API Gateway, configure AWS CloudTrail to record these activities. This setup is critical for maintaining a transparent and secure environment. Follow these steps:

  1. Enable AWS CloudTrail: Make sure AWS CloudTrail is enabled in your AWS account. CloudTrail records all API calls made to AWS services, including API Gateway, and stores the log files in an S3 bucket.
    AWS CloudTrail Documentation
  2. Create a Trail: Create a trail to capture all API Gateway calls. A trail configuration allows you to capture management and data events for API Gateway resources.
    Creating a CloudTrail Trail
  3. Configure Logging for API Gateway: Ensure that API Gateway logging is enabled. You can configure it in the API Gateway console under the logging settings for each API stage.
    Setting up CloudWatch API Logging for API Gateway
  4. Verify Logging and Monitoring: Consistently monitor the logs produced in CloudTrail and CloudWatch. This proactive measure will help in early detection of any unauthorized or suspicious activities.
    AWS Security Hub Recommended Standards

By following these steps, you will enhance the visibility and security of your AWS API Gateway environment, ensuring that all activities are recorded and monitored effectively.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure compliance and detect unauthorized changes in your AWS API Gateway resources, use AWS Config to continuously monitor and evaluate their configurations. AWS Config provides a detailed view of the AWS resource configurations, their relationships, and changes over time.

Heres a step-by-step guide for cloud engineers to implement this control:

  1. Enable AWS Config in your AWS account. Follow the documentation to set up AWS Config by defining an IAM role with the necessary permissions, specifying an S3 bucket to store configuration snapshots, and selecting the AWS resources you want to monitor.
  2. Create a Config Rule to evaluate the configuration of your API Gateway resources. AWS Config provides a set of managed rules, or you can create custom rules using AWS Lambda. For API Gateway, you might use the AWS-managed rule called "api-gateway-gateway-response-check", which checks for best practices and compliance.
  3. Use the AWS Config console or CLI to associate the rules with the API Gateway resources. Define the compliance criteria that the rule will evaluate, such as specific security configurations or limits.
  4. Set up notifications for non-compliance using Amazon SNS. This can help in alerting teams instantaneously if there are unauthorized changes or misconfigurations detected.
  5. Regularly review the compliance status and history of changes in the AWS Config dashboard to maintain best practices and ensure security measures are consistently applied.

Refer to the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices for more details on maintaining a secure configuration for your API Gateway resources.

countermeasure.name: Implement Amazon CloudWatch alarms
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure robust security monitoring of your API Gateway, it's critical to leverage Amazon CloudWatch metrics and alarms. This proactive measure will aid in the prompt detection and response to any anomalies or potential security issues.

Begin by accessing the Amazon CloudWatch console within AWS Management Console. Navigate to the "Metrics" section to ensure you are monitoring the relevant metrics for API Gateway. Key metrics to focus on include:

  • 4XXError: Counts the number of client-side errors (useful for detecting potential abuse).
  • 5XXError: Counts the number of server-side errors (indicates the health of the backend or integration).
  • Count: Number of API requests received (to identify unusual spikes in traffic).
  • Latency: Measures the time taken from the API Gateway receiving a request until it responds (to detect performance degradation).

After identifying these metrics, set up CloudWatch Alarms to notify your security team when any of the thresholds are breached. To do this:

  1. In the CloudWatch console, go to "Alarms" and click on "Create Alarm".
  2. Select the API Gateway metric you want to monitor, such as 4XXError or 5XXError.
  3. Define the appropriate thresholds based on your security policy. For instance, configure an alarm to trigger if the 5XXError exceeds a specific number within a predetermined timeframe.
  4. Set up notification actions, such as sending an alert to an AWS SNS topic, which will forward the notification to the relevant personnel via email or SMS.
  5. Optionally, automate responses using AWS Lambda functions to handle detected anomalies, like throttling suspicious IPs or alerting a security operations center (SOC).

Additionally, ensure compliance with security best practices by reviewing the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices documentation regularly.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance security and ensure that resources within AWS API Gateway are only accessible by authorized entities, it is pivotal to utilize IAM policies that adhere to the principle of least privilege. This approach minimizes the risk of unauthorized access and potential security breaches. Implementing this countermeasure involves creating precise and restrictive IAM policies that grant the minimum necessary permissions required for users or roles to perform their functions.

Follow these steps to implement IAM policies based on the principle of least privilege:

  1. Identify Required Permissions: Determine the exact permissions needed by each user, role, or service account to interact with AWS API Gateway. Avoid granting broad permissions that are not necessary.
  2. Create Custom IAM Policies: Write custom IAM policies that define granular permissions. Use specific actions (e.g., `apigateway:GET`, `apigateway:POST`) and restrict access to the necessary resources (e.g., specific API IDs or stages).
  3. Apply the Policies: Attach the custom IAM policies to the relevant IAM users, groups, or roles. Ensure that the policies are evaluated and tested to confirm they provide the intended access without excess permissions.
  4. Enable Policy Versioning and Logging: Maintain policy versioning to keep track of changes and use AWS CloudTrail for monitoring and logging API Gateway access activity, which helps in auditing and compliance.
  5. Regularly Review and Update Policies: Periodically review the permissions and update IAM policies as needed to adapt to any changes in requirements or security posture.

For more detailed information and best practices on securing your API Gateway using IAM policies, refer to the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices documentation.

countermeasure.name: Implement logging
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure visibility and traceability of all activities occurring in your AWS API Gateway, it is essential to implement monitoring and logging mechanisms using Amazon CloudWatch Logs or Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose. This practice aligns with the security guidelines as specified in the AWS API Gateway Security Best Practices.

Implementation Steps:

  1. Enable API Gateway Execution Logging: Access the API Gateway in the AWS Management Console and navigate to the stage settings. Under the Logs/Tracing tab, enable Access Logging and specify the CloudWatch Logs group. Follow the detailed instructions in the API Gateway Logging Setup Guide.
  2. Set up CloudWatch Logs: If using CloudWatch Logs, ensure that the necessary IAM roles and permissions are in place to allow API Gateway to write logs. Configure log retention policies according to your organizational compliance requirements.
  3. Implement Kinesis Data Firehose: If opting for Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose, create a delivery stream to capture the logs and optionally transform and load them into destination services such as Amazon S3, Amazon Redshift, or Amazon Elasticsearch Service. For integration, refer to Creating an Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose Delivery Stream.
  4. Review and Monitor Logs: Regularly review the logs to detect any anomalies or unauthorized access attempts. Set up CloudWatch Alarms to alert your security team of any suspicious activities.
By adhering to these guidelines and leveraging CloudWatch Logs or Kinesis Data Firehose, you can enhance the security posture of your API Gateway by maintaining comprehensive visibility and traceability of API operations.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS Security Hub
countermeasure.desc:
AWS Security Hub provides a comprehensive view of security alerts and compliance status across AWS accounts for API Gateway implementations. By integrating AWS Security Hub with your AWS API Gateway, you can effectively manage and monitor security risks and ensure adherence to best practices. Follow these steps to implement this countermeasure:
  1. Enable AWS Security Hub: Start by enabling AWS Security Hub in the AWS Management Console. Navigate to the Security Hub dashboard and select "Get Started." Ensure it's activated in the appropriate AWS region where your API Gateway resources are hosted.

    Reference: Setting Up AWS Security Hub

  2. Configure Findings and Insights: AWS Security Hub aggregates findings from various AWS services. Ensure that findings from AWS API Gateway are included. Inspect and prioritize these findings to understand the security and compliance status.

    Reference: Understanding Findings

  3. Enable Security Standards: Activate relevant security standards like the AWS Foundational Security Best Practices standard to receive automated checks for common security configurations and vulnerabilities in your API Gateway setup.

    Reference: AWS Foundational Security Best Practices

  4. Regularly Review and Act: Regularly review the insights and findings provided by Security Hub. Implement recommended actions, such as applying least privilege principles, enabling logging and monitoring, and ensuring proper API Gateway configuration as advised in the AWS API Gateway security best practices.

    Reference: API Gateway Security Best Practices

By systematically implementing these steps, you can ensure that your AWS API Gateway environments are securely managed and compliant with established security best practices.

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access
threat.desc:
General threat description
Improperly configured IAM policies can create vulnerabilities by allowing unauthorized users to access and manipulate API Gateway resources, leading to security breaches.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized users or malicious insiders who exploit weak or overly permissive IAM policies to gain access to API Gateway resources.
Impacts
Unauthorized access, data breaches, service disruptions, and potential exposure of sensitive information.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker identifies an IAM policy that grants overly broad permissions and uses it to access and modify API Gateway settings, potentially disrupting services or exfiltrating data.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Non-compliance with security best practices
threat.desc:
General threat description
Failing to continuously monitor and adhere to security best practices can expose the system to vulnerabilities and lead to non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents include cyber attackers, malicious insiders, and even accidental misconfigurations. Attack vectors can be as diverse as exploiting unpatched vulnerabilities, pivoting through misconfigured services, and taking advantage of outdated security frameworks.
Impacts
The impacts may include data breaches, financial losses, legal penalties, damage to reputation, and disruption of business operations. Regulatory non-compliance can result in fines and restrictions on business activities.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. A cyber attacker identifies unpatched vulnerabilities in the API Gateway and exploits them to gain unauthorized access to sensitive data. 2. Due to lack of continuous monitoring, an internal user accidentally misconfigures security settings, exposing critical resources to the internet. 3. Failure to adhere to encryption best practices leads to data being transmitted in plaintext, which is intercepted by an attacker.

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Delayed threat detection
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without continuous monitoring and alerting, security threats may go undetected for extended periods, increasing the likelihood of significant damage.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat actors can exploit vulnerabilities in your AWS infrastructure that are not promptly identified due to inadequate monitoring and alerting systems. This includes issues like unpatched software, misconfigurations, and unauthorized access attempts.
Impacts
Delayed detection can lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, data loss, and potentially significant downtime. There can also be financial repercussions, reputational damage, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to your AWS API Gateway due to a misconfiguration. Without monitoring, this unauthorized activity goes unnoticed, allowing the attacker to exfiltrate sensitive data over a prolonged period.
2. A vulnerability in an API is exploited, but because continuous monitoring is not in place, the breach is discovered only after considerable damage has been done.
3. An insider modifies configurations maliciously, leading to data leaks or system downtimes that are only detected after client complaints.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Unmonitored changes and activities
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without proper logging, unauthorized changes and activities can go unnoticed, leading to potential vulnerabilities and compliance issues.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Internal employees or external attackers making unauthorized changes, malicious activities occurring within the AWS environment.
Impacts
Data breaches, loss of sensitive information, non-compliance with industry regulations, potential financial and reputational damage.
Example Attack Scenarios
An internal employee alters API configurations without authorization, leading to data exposure. An attacker exploits an API vulnerability, and the lack of logging prevents early detection and response. Audits reveal insufficient logging, resulting in compliance fines.

threat.name: Lack of audit trails
threat.desc:
General threat description
Without audit trails, it is challenging to track changes and access patterns to API Gateway resources, increasing the risk of undetected security incidents.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Threat agents may include external attackers, internal malicious users, or even compromised legitimate users. Attack vectors can include unauthorized access, modification of API configurations, and attempts to exploit vulnerabilities in the API.
Impacts
The lack of audit trails can lead to severe impacts including data breaches, unauthorized access, unnoticed manipulation of sensitive information, and difficulties in incident response and forensic investigation.
Example Attack Scenarios
1. An external attacker gains access to API Gateway and modifies API configurations to exfiltrate sensitive data without detection. 2. An internal employee with malicious intent changes configurations and accesses sensitive customer data, remaining undetected due to the lack of audit trails. 3. A legitimate users account is compromised and used to exploit an API vulnerability, causing data leakage and operational disruptions without raising any alarms.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Configuration drift
threat.desc:
General threat description
Unmonitored configuration changes can lead to configuration drift, making the environment non-compliant with security policies and prone to vulnerabilities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Unauthorized personnel, accidental misconfigurations, or insider threats making untracked changes to the configuration settings.
Impacts
Breach of security policies, increased vulnerability to attacks, potential data breaches, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
Example Attack Scenarios
An insider makes a change to the API Gateway configuration that disables logging, making it difficult to detect malicious activities. Unknown to the security team, an attacker exploits the misconfigured resource, leading to a data breach.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-695
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-695: Use of Low-Level Functionality The product uses low-level functionality that is explicitly prohibited by the framework or specification under which the product is supposed to operate. The use of low-level functionality can violate the specification in unexpected ways that effectively disable built-in protection mechanisms, introduce exploitable inconsistencies, or otherwise expose the functionality to attack.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-79
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-79: Improper Neutralization of Input During Web Page Generation ('Cross-site Scripting') The product does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes user-controllable input before it is placed in output that is used as a web page that is served to other users.

countermeasure.name: Activate deletion protection for your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Enable deletion protection on your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to prevent accidental or unauthorized removal of the load balancer. This setting adds an additional layer of security by ensuring that critical load balancer configurations cannot be deleted without explicit authorization. Activating deletion protection helps safeguard against human error, malicious actions, and potential service disruptions. Regularly review the status of deletion protection to confirm it remains enabled, ensuring continuous protection of your ALB and the applications it supports.

reference.name: Application Load Balancers

countermeasure.name: Configure strictest desync mitigation mode for your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Set your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to operate using the strictest desynchronization (desync) mitigation mode available. This configuration helps defend against HTTP request smuggling and other desynchronization attacks that can exploit differences in how HTTP requests are processed between clients and servers. By enabling the strictest desync mitigation mode, you ensure that the ALB consistently handles incoming traffic in a secure manner, reducing the risk of these attacks and maintaining the integrity of data transmission. Regularly review and update this setting to align with best practices and evolving security threats.

countermeasure.name: Deploy AWS WAF with managed rules to protect applications behind your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Implement AWS Web Application Firewall (WAF) in conjunction with your AWS Application Load Balancer to protect web applications from common web exploits and vulnerabilities. Utilize AWS WAF's managed rule sets to automatically block known threats, such as SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), and other common attacks, before they reach your application. Configure and customize WAF rules based on the specific needs of your application to ensure comprehensive protection. Regularly review and update the WAF rules to adapt to new threats and application changes, ensuring continuous security. Integrate WAF logging with AWS CloudWatch for monitoring and alerting on suspicious activity.

reference.name: Web Application Firewall, Web API Protection - AWS WAF

countermeasure.name: Enable access logging for your Application Load Balancer and integrate with CloudWatch and CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc: Enable access logging on your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to capture detailed records of all incoming traffic. Integrate these logs with AWS CloudWatch and AWS CloudTrail to monitor for suspicious activities and unauthorized access attempts. Set up automated alerts within CloudWatch to notify your team of any anomalies or potential security incidents. Regularly review the access logs to identify patterns or activities that may indicate security threats, and take proactive measures to address any identified risks. This control ensures that all traffic through the ALB is tracked and analyzed, enhancing the security and resilience of your application.

reference.name: Enable access logs for your Application Load Balancer

countermeasure.name: Enable cross-zone load balancing for your Application Load Balancer
countermeasure.desc: Ensure that cross-zone load balancing is enabled on your AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) to evenly distribute incoming traffic across all available zones within the region. This configuration enhances fault tolerance by preventing any single availability zone from becoming a bottleneck or single point of failure. It also improves resource efficiency by balancing the load across multiple zones, ensuring optimal performance and reducing the risk of overloading individual resources. Regularly verify that cross-zone load balancing is enabled and functioning as intended to maintain high availability and resilience of your application.

reference.name: Enable cross-zone load balancing

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Accidental or malicious deletion of Load Balancer
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Accidental or malicious deletion of an AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) occurs when the load balancer is unintentionally or deliberately removed, disrupting traffic distribution and causing service outages.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Human Error: Mistaken deletion during routine tasks.
  • Malicious Insider: An authorized user intentionally deletes the ALB.
  • Compromised Credentials: Attackers gain unauthorized access and delete the ALB.

Impacts

  • Service Downtime: Immediate interruption in traffic routing, leading to application unavailability.
  • Revenue Loss: Downtime can lead to financial losses and damage to customer trust.
  • Operational Disruption: Resources are diverted to restore service, causing further delays.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Accidental Deletion: An admin mistakenly deletes the ALB during maintenance, causing downtime until reconfiguration.
  2. Malicious Insider: A disgruntled employee deletes the ALB to cause service outages.
  3. Credential Compromise: An attacker deletes the ALB after gaining unauthorized access to the AWS console.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Lack of logging and monitoring in AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) refers to the absence or inadequacy of tracking and reviewing activities related to the ALB. Without proper logging, security incidents, misconfigurations, or unauthorized access attempts may go undetected, leaving the system vulnerable to prolonged risks and making it difficult to investigate incidents.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Misconfiguration: Logging and monitoring features not properly enabled or configured.
  • Negligence: Failure to regularly review logs or set up alerts for suspicious activities.
  • Malicious Actors: Exploiting the lack of monitoring to perform unauthorized actions undetected.

Impacts

  • Undetected Security Incidents: Without logs, security breaches can go unnoticed.
  • Difficulty in Incident Response: Lack of detailed logs complicates forensic investigations and response efforts.
  • Non-Compliance: Failure to maintain proper logging may lead to non-compliance with regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Undetected Breach: An attacker exploits a vulnerability in an application behind the ALB, but due to lack of logging, the breach remains unnoticed for an extended period.
  2. Misconfiguration Overlooked: A misconfiguration in the ALB allows traffic that should have been blocked. Without monitoring, this issue persists, exposing the application to potential attacks.
  3. Failed Audit: During a compliance audit, the organization fails to provide adequate logs for the ALB, leading to penalties or loss of certification.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure cross-zone Load Balancing
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insecure cross-zone load balancing in AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) refers to the improper configuration of traffic distribution across multiple availability zones. If cross-zone load balancing is not enabled or is misconfigured, traffic may be unevenly distributed, leading to potential single points of failure, inefficient resource utilization, and reduced fault tolerance.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Misconfiguration: Failure to enable cross-zone load balancing or incorrect settings that prevent proper traffic distribution.
  • Resource Limitations: Uneven distribution of traffic that causes some zones to be overburdened while others remain underutilized.
  • Fault Tolerance Issues: Lack of redundancy due to improper load balancing can make the system vulnerable to zone failures.

Impacts

  • Single Points of Failure: Without proper cross-zone balancing, a failure in a heavily burdened zone can lead to significant service disruption.
  • Inefficient Resource Utilization: Overloaded zones can lead to poor performance and increased latency, while underutilized zones waste resources.
  • Reduced Fault Tolerance: The inability to distribute traffic evenly across zones can reduce the overall fault tolerance of the application, making it more susceptible to outages.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Zone Failure: Cross-zone load balancing is disabled, and most traffic is routed to a single availability zone. When that zone experiences an outage, the application becomes unavailable.
  2. Performance Degradation: A misconfigured ALB routes most traffic to one zone, overloading instances in that zone while instances in other zones remain idle, leading to slow response times and poor user experience.
  3. Increased Latency: Due to improper load balancing, some users experience higher latency because their requests are handled by overburdened instances in a particular zone, while other instances are underused.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1526 - Cloud Service Discovery

threat.name: Vulnerabilities in web applications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Vulnerabilities in web applications behind an AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) refer to security weaknesses in the applications that can be exploited by attackers. These vulnerabilities may include SQL injection, cross-site scripting (XSS), insecure deserialization, and other common web application flaws. If not properly mitigated, these vulnerabilities can be exploited to compromise the application, steal data, or gain unauthorized access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Malicious Actors: Attackers actively scan for and exploit vulnerabilities in web applications to gain unauthorized access or cause harm.
  • Automated Bots: Bots can systematically probe web applications for known vulnerabilities and exploit them if found.
  • Inadequate Security Practices: Development teams may inadvertently introduce vulnerabilities through coding errors or inadequate security testing.

Impacts

  • Data Breach: Sensitive information may be accessed or stolen, leading to significant financial and reputational damage.
  • Application Compromise: Attackers can gain control over the application, altering functionality or using it as a launching point for further attacks.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Exploited vulnerabilities can result in violations of data protection regulations, leading to fines and penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. SQL Injection: An attacker exploits a SQL injection vulnerability in the web application to access the backend database, stealing sensitive user information.
  2. Cross-Site Scripting (XSS): An attacker injects malicious scripts into a vulnerable web application, which are then executed in the browsers of unsuspecting users, leading to data theft or session hijacking.
  3. Insecure Deserialization: A vulnerability in the applications deserialization process is exploited by an attacker to execute arbitrary code, leading to complete system compromise.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Desynchronization attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Desynchronization attacks on AWS Application Load Balancer (ALB) involve manipulating the sequence or synchronization of HTTP requests and responses, leading to vulnerabilities like HTTP request smuggling. These attacks can allow malicious actors to bypass security controls, inject malicious payloads, or interfere with normal application operations.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Malicious Actors: Attackers exploit gaps in how the ALB processes and synchronizes HTTP requests and responses.
  • Misconfiguration: Improper settings in the ALB that allow desync vulnerabilities to be exploited.
  • Complex Web Traffic: Applications with complex, multi-part requests that are more susceptible to desync issues.

Impacts

  • Bypassed Security Controls: Attackers can bypass firewalls or WAF rules, leading to potential data breaches or unauthorized actions.
  • Request Smuggling: Malicious actors can manipulate HTTP requests to perform actions they shouldn't be allowed to.
  • Service Disruption: Desync attacks can cause disruptions in how applications process web traffic, potentially leading to outages or degraded performance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Request Smuggling: An attacker sends a specially crafted HTTP request that takes advantage of desynchronization, bypassing the WAF and gaining unauthorized access to sensitive application areas.
  2. Bypass Security Filters: Due to a desync issue, a malicious payload is able to slip through security filters that would normally block it, leading to data exfiltration.
  3. Service Degradation: A desynchronization attack causes the ALB to misroute traffic, leading to significant delays and potential service outages.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-20
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-20: Improper Input Validation The product receives input or data, but it does not validate or incorrectly validates that the input has the properties that are required to process the data safely and correctly.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

countermeasure.name: Encrypt Auto Scaling data at rest and in transit
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that all data related to AWS Auto Scaling, including configuration files and logs, is encrypted both at rest and in transit using AWS encryption services.

Encrypt Data at Rest:

  • Store configuration files in S3 or EFS with server-side encryption using AWS KMS.
  • Encrypt CloudTrail and CloudWatch Logs using AWS KMS.

Encrypt Data in Transit:

  • Use HTTPS (TLS) for data transmission.

Manage Access:

  • Apply IAM policies for least privilege access to encryption keys.

Monitor Compliance:

  • Use AWS Config to ensure encryption policies are followed.

reference.name: Security in Application Auto Scaling

standard.ref: SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1043 - Credential Access Protection
SC-28 PROTECTION OF INFORMATION AT REST

countermeasure.name: Implement service-linked roles for Auto Scaling
countermeasure.desc:
Implement service-linked roles for AWS Auto Scaling to provide permissions for AWS services to perform actions on your behalf securely. This ensures that Auto Scaling can function properly while adhering to the principle of least privilege.

Create Service-Linked Role:

  • Use the AWS Management Console, CLI, or SDK to create a service-linked role specifically for Auto Scaling.
  • The role is predefined with the necessary permissions for Auto Scaling to operate securely.

Assign Service-Linked Role:

  • Ensure that the Auto Scaling service is using the created service-linked role to perform its operations.

Review Role Permissions:

  • Regularly review the permissions assigned to the service-linked role to ensure they are up to date and adhere to security best practices.

Monitor Role Activity:

  • Use AWS CloudTrail to monitor and log the activities performed by the service-linked role for auditing and compliance purposes.

By following these steps, you can securely delegate necessary permissions to AWS Auto Scaling while maintaining tight security controls.

reference.name: Security in Application Auto Scaling

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.DS-5: Protections against data leaks are implemented

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1052 - User Account Control

countermeasure.name: Restrict traffic with security groups for Auto Scaling instances
countermeasure.desc:
Configure security groups to restrict traffic to and from AWS Auto Scaling instances, allowing only necessary ports and protocols. This enhances security by limiting exposure to potential threats.

Create Security Groups:

  • Define security groups specifically for Auto Scaling instances.

Restrict Inbound Traffic:

  • Allow only necessary inbound ports and protocols (e.g., HTTP/HTTPS for web servers, SSH for management).
  • Specify trusted IP ranges for access where applicable.

Restrict Outbound Traffic:

  • Allow only necessary outbound ports and protocols required for instance functionality.

Regularly Review and Update Rules:

  • Periodically audit security group rules to ensure they adhere to the principle of least privilege.
  • Adjust rules as necessary based on changes in application requirements or security policies.

reference.name: Identity and Access Management for Application Auto Scaling

countermeasure.name: Test scaling policies in staging environment
countermeasure.desc:
Test all AWS Auto Scaling policies in a staging environment before deploying them to production. This ensures their effectiveness and stability, minimizing the risk of configuration errors that could impact application performance and availability.

Set Up Staging Environment:

  • Mirror the production environment in staging to accurately test scaling policies.

Deploy and Test:

  • Implement scaling policies in the staging environment.
  • Conduct load tests and monitor the behavior of the scaling policies under various scenarios.

Review and Adjust:

  • Analyze test results and adjust policies as necessary to ensure optimal performance and stability.

Deploy to Production:

  • Once verified, apply the tested and adjusted scaling policies to the production environment.

reference.name: Security in Application Auto Scaling

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Unauthorized access to Auto Scaling resources
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Unauthorized access to AWS Auto Scaling resources can result in unintended changes to scaling policies, unauthorized scaling actions, and potential misuse of resources, leading to performance issues and security breaches.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, accidental insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Compromised IAM credentials
    • Misconfigured IAM roles and policies
    • Exploiting application vulnerabilities
    • Lack of multi-factor authentication (MFA)

Impacts

  • Resource Misuse: Over-provisioning or under-provisioning of resources
  • Data Breach: Unauthorized access to sensitive configuration data
  • Operational Disruption: Service performance issues
  • Financial Loss: Increased costs due to unauthorized scaling actions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Compromised Credentials: An attacker uses stolen AWS credentials to modify Auto Scaling policies, leading to resource misuse.
  2. Misconfigured IAM Roles: Broad permissions in IAM roles allow unauthorized changes to Auto Scaling settings.
  3. Insider Threat: An employee alters scaling policies to disrupt services.
  4. Application Exploitation: Exploiting a vulnerability to gain elevated permissions and change Auto Scaling configurations.

Implementing strict IAM policies, enabling MFA, regularly auditing roles, and monitoring activities can mitigate these risks.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data breaches due to insufficient data protection
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Data breaches due to insufficient data protection in AWS Auto Scaling involve unauthorized access to sensitive data because of inadequate encryption, misconfiguration, or weak data handling practices.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, accidental insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Unencrypted data at rest or in transit
    • Misconfigured storage settings
    • Exploitation of weak access controls
    • Insufficient data handling practices

Impacts

  • Confidentiality Breach: Exposure of sensitive data, such as customer information or proprietary business data
  • Data Integrity Compromise: Unauthorized modification of data
  • Operational Disruption: Service interruptions and loss of data integrity
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of trust from customers and stakeholders
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Potential fines and legal action due to failure to comply with data protection regulations

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unencrypted Storage: An attacker gains access to unencrypted storage containing sensitive data, leading to data theft.
  2. Misconfigured Permissions: Improper configuration of S3 bucket permissions results in public access to sensitive data.
  3. Insider Threat: An employee with access to sensitive data exports it without proper authorization.
  4. Man-in-the-Middle Attack: An attacker intercepts data in transit due to lack of encryption, gaining access to sensitive information.

Implementing data encryption, configuring storage settings securely, enforcing strict access controls, and following best practices for data handling can mitigate these risks.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Misconfiguration of Auto Scaling policies
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Misconfiguration of AWS Auto Scaling policies can lead to improper scaling actions, resulting in over-provisioning or under-provisioning of resources. This can negatively impact application performance, availability, and cost efficiency.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Developers, DevOps engineers, external attackers (through compromised accounts)
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Incorrect scaling thresholds and metrics
    • Overly aggressive or conservative scaling policies
    • Manual errors during policy configuration
    • Lack of testing and validation for scaling policies

Impacts

  • Resource Misuse: Over-provisioning leads to unnecessary costs, while under-provisioning causes performance degradation.
  • Operational Disruption: Unstable application performance and potential downtime.
  • Financial Loss: Increased costs due to inefficient resource scaling.
  • Reputation Damage: Customer dissatisfaction due to poor application performance and reliability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Incorrect Thresholds: A developer sets CPU utilization thresholds too low, causing Auto Scaling to add more instances than necessary, leading to high costs.
  2. Overly Aggressive Scaling: An overly aggressive scaling policy scales up resources too quickly in response to minor traffic spikes, resulting in resource waste.
  3. Lack of Testing: A misconfigured scaling policy is applied directly to production without testing, leading to unexpected behavior and service disruptions.
  4. Manual Configuration Errors: An engineer manually configures a scaling policy with incorrect parameters, causing the application to scale inadequately during peak load.

By implementing these countermeasures, you can mitigate the risks associated with misconfiguration of Auto Scaling policies and ensure that your application scales efficiently and cost-effectively.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1578.005 - Modify Cloud Compute Configurations

threat.name: Network vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description 

Network vulnerabilities in AWS Auto Scaling involve weaknesses in the network configuration that can be exploited by attackers to gain unauthorized access, disrupt services, or exfiltrate data. These vulnerabilities can arise from improper network segmentation, insecure protocols, or misconfigured network security settings.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploitation of open ports and services
    • Man-in-the-Middle (MitM) attacks
    • DDoS attacks targeting network infrastructure
    • Exploiting insecure network protocols

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers gain access to sensitive data and resources
  • Data Breach: Exposure of confidential information
  • Service Disruption: Downtime or degraded performance due to network attacks
  • Reputation Damage: Loss of customer trust due to perceived security weaknesses
  • Financial Loss: Costs associated with mitigating breaches and service disruptions

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open Ports: An attacker scans for and exploits open ports on Auto Scaling instances, gaining unauthorized access to the network.
  2. MitM Attack: An attacker intercepts and alters communications between Auto Scaling components by exploiting insecure network protocols.
  3. DDoS Attack: Attackers flood the network with traffic, overwhelming the infrastructure and causing service outages.
  4. Insecure Protocols: An attacker exploits vulnerabilities in outdated or insecure network protocols to compromise data integrity and confidentiality.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

weakness.name: CWE-269
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-269: Improper Privilege Management The product does not properly assign, modify, track, or check privileges for an actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-494
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-494: Download of Code Without Integrity Check The product downloads source code or an executable from a remote location and executes the code without sufficiently verifying the origin and integrity of the code. An attacker can execute malicious code by compromising the host server, performing DNS spoofing, or modifying the code in transit.

weakness.name: CWE-682
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-682: Incorrect Calculation The product performs a calculation that generates incorrect or unintended results that are later used in security-critical decisions or resource management. When product performs a security-critical calculation incorrectly, it might lead to incorrect resource allocations, incorrect privilege assignments, or failed comparisons among other things. Many of the direct results of an incorrect calculation can lead to even larger problems such as failed protection mechanisms or even arbitrary code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-697
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-697: Incorrect Comparison The product compares two entities in a security-relevant context, but the comparison is incorrect, which may lead to resultant weaknesses.

countermeasure.name: Adopt capacity-aware, multi-Availability Zone placement strategies
countermeasure.desc:
Step-by-Step Guidance for Implementing the Countermeasure:

1. Use Multiple Instance Types and Launch Templates

To reduce potential disruptions caused by infrastructure limitations within a single Availability Zone (AZ), leverage multiple EC2 instance types and launch templates:

  • Analyze workload requirements to select compatible EC2 instance families/types that meet compute, memory, storage, and networking needs.
  • Create launch templates for each instance type, specifying key configuration details such as AMI, instance type, security group, and block device mappings. Follow AWS Launch Template Guidance for detailed instructions.
  • Test launch templates in your development environment to confirm compatibility and performance.

2. Configure Auto Scaling Groups Across Multiple Availability Zone Subnets

To achieve high availability and fault tolerance, distribute workloads across multiple subnets tied to different AZs.

  • Identify subnets associated with distinct AZs within your VPC. Ensure your VPC is configured correctly (Subnet Documentation).
  • Create or update Auto Scaling Groups (ASGs) to span these subnets, specifying multiple AZs during ASG configuration.
  • Set ASG scaling policies based on workload demand or health checks to dynamically allocate resources.

3. Monitor and Plan Service Quotas Per Availability Zone

AWS imposes quotas on resources per region and AZ, which can lead to capacity constraints. To avoid service disruptions:

  • Use the AWS Service Quotas dashboard to monitor quotas for critical resources like EC2 instances, EBS volumes, and Elastic IPs.
  • Plan resource allocations carefully while scaling across AZs and request quota increases as needed using AWS Service Quotas Console.
  • Automate monitoring of service quotas using Amazon CloudWatch.

4. Validate That Critical Workloads Can Start in Alternate Availability Zones

Ensure failover capabilities for critical workloads in case one AZ becomes unavailable:

  • Test the deployment of your applications in alternate AZs by simulating failure scenarios.
  • Review resource dependencies (e.g., EBS volumes and IP addresses) and ensure configurations allow for quick replication or reassignment in another AZ.
  • Create Disaster Recovery (DR) plans to guide workloads' transition within minutes of AZ disruptions.

5. Continuously Evaluate and Audit Configuration

Regularly audit your architecture and workload distribution across AZs to identify security and operational risks.

  • Use AWS Config to set up rules for continuous compliance checks.
  • Review AWS Trusted Advisor recommendations to optimize availability configurations and verify AZ balance.
  • Conduct routine penetration testing and failure drills for detecting vulnerabilities and validating failover mechanisms.

References

  • AWS EC2 Availability Zones Documentation
  • AWS Global Infrastructure
  • AWS EC2 Launch Templates
  • AWS Service Quotas
  • Amazon CloudWatch
  • AWS Config

countermeasure.name: Constrain egress per Availability Zone using NAT, routes, and endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
Step 1: Deploy NAT Gateways Per Availability Zone

To ensure high availability and fault tolerance, deploy a NAT Gateway in each Availability Zone within your VPC.

  • Navigate to the Amazon VPC console.
  • In the navigation pane, select NAT Gateways and then click Create NAT Gateway.
  • Select the subnet corresponding to the Availability Zone where the NAT Gateway will reside.
  • Allocate or select an Elastic IP address to associate with the NAT Gateway.
  • Repeat this process for all relevant Availability Zones in your VPC.

Step 2: Bind Private Subnets to Same-Zone NAT Gateways

Assign route tables to private subnets and ensure traffic destined for the internet is routed through NAT Gateways in the same Availability Zone.

  • In the Amazon VPC console, select Route Tables.
  • Choose a route table associated with a private subnet.
  • Edit routes to add a destination of 0.0.0.0/0 and set the target to the NAT Gateway's ID specific to the same Availability Zone.
  • Associate the route table with the private subnet in the Subnet Associations tab.
  • Repeat these steps for all private subnets to ensure zonal redundancy.

Step 3: Restrict Egress with Route Tables and Network ACLs

Limit the outbound traffic from private subnets to the minimum necessary to reduce the attack surface.

  • Configure the route table to direct only necessary traffic to specific destinations via the NAT Gateway.
  • Set up Network ACLs (NACLs) to explicitly allow specific protocols, ports, and IP ranges necessary for your applications.
  • Ensure a default "Deny" rule for other outbound traffic.

Step 4: Prefer VPC Endpoints for AWS Service Traffic

Leverage VPC endpoints (interface or gateway endpoints) to route traffic to AWS services directly within the AWS network, avoiding public internet routes.

  • Navigate to the Amazon VPC console and select Endpoints.
  • Click Create Endpoint and select the desired AWS service, such as S3 or DynamoDB.
  • Choose the appropriate Endpoint type (gateway or interface) based on the service.
  • Associate the endpoint with the relevant route tables within your VPC.
  • Test and verify traffic to AWS services flows through the endpoint instead of the NAT Gateway.

References

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • Amazon VPC NAT Gateway Documentation
  • Amazon VPC Endpoints Documentation
  • Network ACLs Documentation

countermeasure.name: Design multi-Availability Zone architectures for fault isolation
countermeasure.desc:
To improve the security and resiliency of your workload in AWS, follow the step-by-step guidance below for distributing critical resources across multiple Availability Zones (AZs):

  1. Determine the number of Availability Zones and Regions: Analyze the workload requirements to identify suitable AWS Regions and the number of Availability Zones available in each Region. Refer to the AWS Availability Zone documentation to find detailed information.
  2. Create separate subnets for each Availability Zone: Design your Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) with subnets distributed across multiple AZs. Each AZ should have a dedicated subnet to ensure proper resource isolation and failover capabilities. Follow the guidelines in the AWS VPC User Guide for subnet creation.
  3. Configure Auto Scaling Groups across multiple subnets: Create an Auto Scaling Group (ASG) and specify the subnets in multiple AZs to ensure instances can launch in alternative AZs during an outage. Enable dynamic scaling policies to maintain a consistent level of performance. Review the AWS Auto Scaling documentation for step-by-step setup instructions.
  4. Use Multi-AZ deployments for managed services: For database services like Amazon RDS, enable Multi-AZ deployment to provision a standby replica in a secondary AZ. This setup automatically performs failover during disruptions. Additionally, validate Multi-AZ support for other managed services, such as Amazon ElastiCache and Amazon DynamoDB. Use the Amazon RDS Multi-AZ documentation for more information.
  5. Implement replication across Availability Zones: Configure data replication mechanisms that span AZs for critical datasets. For example, enable S3 cross-region replication or use the replication features provided by databases like Amazon DynamoDB Global Tables and Amazon Aurora. Reference the Amazon S3 Replication documentation.
  6. Validate failover and recovery processes: Conduct periodic failover testing to ensure seamless transitions during AZ outages. Validate that your Auto Scaling Groups, Multi-AZ services, and data replication mechanisms work as intended under simulated failure scenarios. Review AWS Well-Architected Framework guidelines for best practices.
  7. Monitor AZ health and implement alerts: Use AWS CloudWatch to monitor the performance and health of resources across AZs. Create alarms to detect anomalies or failures early, and set up SNS notifications to ensure real-time alerts for critical events. Refer to the Amazon CloudWatch documentation for guidance.
  8. Optimize cost and compliance considerations: Ensure your workload is distributed efficiently to avoid unnecessary costs while adhering to regional compliance requirements. Use AWS Cost Explorer and AWS Config to maintain visibility into cost and security configurations. Refer to the AWS Cost Explorer documentation.

References

  • AWS Availability Zones in EC2
  • AWS Global Infrastructure and Availability Zones
  • AWS VPC User Guide
  • Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling
  • Amazon RDS Multi-AZ
  • Amazon S3 Replication
  • AWS Well-Architected Framework
  • Amazon CloudWatch
  • AWS Cost Explorer

countermeasure.name: Harden per-Availability Zone network segmentation
countermeasure.desc:
Follow these steps to implement the security countermeasure for AWS Availability Zones effectively:

  1. Design the Subnet Architecture:
    • Create distinct public and private subnets in each Availability Zone within your VPC.
    • Ensure public subnets are used for resources requiring internet access, such as load balancers.
    • Place resources such as application servers or databases in private subnets to prevent direct internet exposure.
  2. Configure Security Groups:
    • Apply the principle of least privilege when creating and configuring security groups. Ensure they allow only explicitly required traffic.
    • Examples: Restrict access to application servers to specific IP ranges or allow database ports only from application servers.
    • Allocate separate security groups for different resource tiers (e.g., web, application, database).
  3. Set Up Network Access Control Lists (NACLs):
    • Create NACLs for subnets to define fine-grained network-level policies for inbound and outbound traffic.
    • Implement deny rules for traffic that must explicitly be blocked, alongside allowing necessary traffic.
    • Regularly review NACL rules to optimize security settings.
  4. Create Dedicated Route Tables:
    • Assign dedicated route tables for each subnet tier to ensure isolation and control over routing.
    • Public subnets route tables should include routes to an internet gateway (IGW), allowing internet-based communication.
    • Private subnets should have routes directing traffic through a NAT gateway or VPC endpoint, without routing traffic to the IGW.
  5. Leverage VPC Endpoints:
    • Use VPC endpoints to privately access AWS services such as S3, DynamoDB, or Systems Manager without the need for public internet access.
    • Subnet traffic directed to VPC endpoints will stay entirely within the AWS network, improving security.
    • Ensure proper IAM policies on the VPC endpoints to enforce access controls for the associated AWS service.
  6. Regularly Review Routes:
    • Inspect route tables periodically to identify any unintended routes that may expose resources to unauthorized access or create conflicts.
    • Remove unnecessary routes and test changes thoroughly before deployment.
    • Monitor changes in route tables using AWS Config to ensure compliance with your network security policies.

For further details and best practices, consult the following references:

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • AWS Infrastructure Security Basics

countermeasure.name: Implement Availability Zone-scoped logging and monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Step-by-Step Guidance for Implementing the Security Countermeasure:

1. Enable VPC Flow Logs for Each Subnet

VPC Flow Logs provide visibility into the IP traffic handled by your VPC. By enabling flow logs at the subnet level, you gain granular insights into traffic patterns and potential issues.

  • Log into the AWS Management Console.
  • Navigate to the VPC section of the console.
  • Select the target VPC and then locate the specific subnets within it.
  • Click on the subnet you want to enable logs for and choose Create Flow Log.
  • Specify the destination for the logs (e.g., CloudWatch Logs or an Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Choose appropriate filters (e.g., All, Accept, Reject).
  • Save your settings and repeat for all relevant subnets.

2. Enable AWS CloudTrail Across All Regions

AWS CloudTrail provides event history and auditing capabilities for actions occurring within your AWS account. You should ensure CloudTrail is globally enabled and centralized for all regions.

  • Navigate to the CloudTrail console.
  • Click Create trail.
  • Provide a name for your trail and enable logging across All Regions.
  • Specify where logs should be stored (e.g., an Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Configure optional encryption and permission settings for enhanced security.
  • Validate the trail creation and ensure monitoring is enabled for Availability Zone activity.

3. Centralize Logs in Amazon CloudWatch Metrics/Alarms

To gain insights into anomalous traffic behavior and monitor configuration drift, integrate logs with CloudWatch and set up metrics and alarms with dimensions for Availability Zones.

  • Navigate to the CloudWatch console.
  • Ensure you have enabled log ingestion from VPC Flow Logs and AWS CloudTrail.
  • Inside the console, create Log Groups to centralize logs related to traffic patterns in specific Availability Zones.
  • Define Metric Filters to extract key metrics from logs, such as large spikes in denied traffic or unexpected changes.
  • Create alarms using CloudWatch thresholds to alert when unusual behavior is identified.
  • Test alarms and validate their alignment with Availability Zone identifiers.

4. Continuously Monitor for Configuration Drift

Configuration drift occurs when the infrastructure gradually diverges from its intended state. Detect and mitigate it using AWS Config and automated corrective actions.

  • Enable AWS Config to monitor resource configurations across your account.
  • Use Config rules to track compliance with security best practices, focusing on VPC security, flow logs, and trail settings.
  • Create custom Config rules to log and alert for changes in subnet configurations or flow log status.
  • Integrate relevant insights into CloudWatch dashboards for centralized visibility.

5. Detect Anomalous Traffic Patterns

Leverage specific AWS tools to detect unusual or harmful traffic patterns across Availability Zones.

  • Integrate Amazon GuardDuty to analyze flow logs and CloudTrail events for threats.
  • Enable DNS threat detection and monitor unusual spikes or requests within Availability Zones.
  • Regularly audit metric alarms and identify high-traffic periods that dont correlate with expected behavior.
  • Implement runtime protection tools to respond to live traffic anomalies.

References

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • AWS Infrastructure Security Basics
  • VPC Flow Logs User Guide
  • CloudTrail Console User Guide
  • Amazon CloudWatch Logs Monitoring
  • What Is AWS Config?
  • What is Amazon GuardDuty?

countermeasure.name: Restrict inter-Availability Zone connectivity with least privilege
countermeasure.desc:
To improve the security of AWS Availability Zone implementations, follow these comprehensive steps:

  1. Scope Security Group Rules to Necessary Ports and Sources:

    • Decide which ports are required based on the specific functionality of the application or workloads hosted within the Availability Zone.
    • Restrict inbound and outbound traffic to only the ranges of IPs or VPC resources that require access.
    • For each security group, use precise CIDR ranges or specific AWS resources (i.e., other security groups or instance IDs) to define allowed traffic. Ensure the rules comply with the principle of least privilege.
    • Review the configurations frequently to ensure that only necessary access is permitted and to detect any unused or overly permissive rules.
    • To implement, navigate to the Security Groups section in your AWS Management Console or use the AWS CLI/SDK.

  2. Segment Tiers per Availability Zone:

    • Design your application tiers (e.g., web, app, and database tiers) to align with specific Availability Zones. This provides a natural layer of segmentation for additional security.
    • Configure security group rules to ensure that lateral movement is restricted between tiers, except for explicitly required communication flows. For example, only allow the application tier to communicate with the database tier.
    • Use subnet segmentation within Availability Zones to isolate traffic dynamically based on the application tier's role. Each tier can be assigned its own subnet with distinct configurations.

  3. Use ALB/NLB Target Groups with Controlled Registration Across Zones:

    • Configure Target Groups in your Application Load Balancer (ALB) or Network Load Balancer (NLB) to register instances based on specific Availability Zones.
    • Verify that health checks are configured properly to ensure that only healthy instances are registered in Target Groups.
    • Control registration by tagging or labeling instances according to their purpose and zone, and create IAM policies or scripts for automated instance registration based on exclusion or inclusion criteria.
    • Use listener rules in your ALB or NLB to enforce zone-specific routing if necessary.

  4. Review NACLs to Minimize Lateral Movement:

    • For each subnet in your VPC, review Network Access Control List (NACL) rules to ensure that only legitimate traffic flows are allowed.
    • Block unnecessary intra-zone traffic by explicitly denying overly permissive rules, especially those allowing access between subnets of different tiers unnecessarily.
    • Use deny rules explicitly where feasible to block traffic that should not have lateral access across subnets and Availability Zones.
    • Regularly audit NACL rules using AWS Config to ensure compliance with best practices and monitor for drift or outdated configurations.

References

  • VPC Security Best Practices
  • Amazon EC2 Security Groups
  • What Is an Application Load Balancer?
  • Network Load Balancer Overview
  • Network ACL Overview
  • AWS Config Evaluation of Rules

countermeasure.name: Use stable Availability Zone ids and avoid hardcoded names
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure resources in AWS are distributed across distinct physical zones and maintain high availability, adhere to the following steps:

  1. Understand AWS Availability Zone IDs:
    • Availability Zones are distinct from "names" such as us-east-1a. These names vary per account due to internal mapping, but Availability Zone IDs (e.g., use-az1) remain consistent across accounts.
    • Refer to the AWS documentation on Availability Zone IDs to familiarize yourself with this concept: Availability Zone Concepts.
  2. Use Programmatic Discovery via the AWS CLI or SDK to dynamically retrieve Availability Zone information:
    • Run the following AWS CLI command to list all Availability Zones within a region:aws ec2 describe-availability-zones --region REGION_NAMEReplace REGION_NAME with your selected region (e.g., us-east-1).
    • In the output, reference the ZoneId fields (e.g., use-az1). These IDs can be used reliably to distribute resources across distinct physical locations.
  3. Automate Resource Spreading Across Zones:
    • Design your infrastructure to programmatically spread workloads across the unique ZoneId values using orchestration tools such as AWS CloudFormation, AWS SDK (for Python boto3 or Java SDK), or APIs.
    • Create deployment logic to verify that the resources are evenly distributed by cross-checking the ZoneId mappings during deployment or updates.
  4. Document the ZoneId mappings:
    • Maintain a record of Availability Zone IDs and their associated resources for each deployment or major change.
    • Store this documentation securely in a versioned repository or centralized configuration management system, such as AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store or an internal inventory system.
  5. Continuously Audit Resource Placement:
    • Periodically run the DescribeAvailabilityZones API or CLI command and validate the resource placement against the mapping records for consistency.
    • Update deployment documentation promptly if new zones are added or existing ones are modified.

References

  • Availability Zone Concepts
