usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Resource mismanagement
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Resource mismanagement in AWS EC2 encompasses the improper allocation, oversight, and operation of EC2 resources. This can include inefficient use of computing power, storage, and network configurations, leading to increased costs and reduced system performance.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Primary agents include internal misconfigurations, lack of resource oversight, and inadequate scaling strategies which may fail to meet system demands or optimize costs effectively.

Impacts

Consequences of resource mismanagement can include overspending, performance bottlenecks, and potential service interruptions, all of which can negatively affect the operational efficiency and economic viability of the system.

Example Attack Scenarios

A typical scenario might involve an organization that has over-provisioned EC2 instances without proper load balancing or auto-scaling configurations. This results in high operational costs and underutilized resources, impacting the budget and overall system efficiency.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Failover and recovery issues
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Failover and recovery issues in AWS EC2 pertain to the challenges and failures that can arise during the process of recovering from hardware or software failures. Proper management is crucial to ensure continuous availability and data integrity.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

The main agents include system malfunctions, configuration errors, and external disruptions that impact the EC2 environment. These can be exacerbated by inadequate redundancy planning or flawed recovery procedures.

Impacts

Ineffective failover and recovery strategies can lead to significant service disruptions, data loss, and prolonged downtime, affecting business operations and trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

A scenario could involve an EC2 instance failing to switch over to a standby in another Availability Zone due to misconfigured failover processes. This results in an outage, where critical applications remain offline until manual intervention is performed, leading to potential data loss and service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate access controls
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Inadequate access controls in AWS EC2 involve insufficient management of permissions and access rights to EC2 resources, which can expose sensitive data and computing processes to unauthorized users or malicious entities.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include unauthorized users who may exploit weak authentication and authorization processes to gain access to EC2 instances. Misconfigured IAM roles and security group settings are common vectors.

Impacts

The consequences can range from data breaches and unauthorized system modifications to complete system takeover, compromising data integrity and organizational security.

Example Attack Scenarios

An example scenario could involve an attacker exploiting overly permissive IAM role configurations to access and manipulate EC2 instances. This unauthorized access could lead to data leakage, system disruptions, or the deployment of malicious software within the network.

threat.name: System vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

System Vulnerabilities in AWS EC2 refer to weaknesses in the EC2 infrastructure that can be exploited by attackers. These vulnerabilities may stem from outdated software, misconfigured systems, or inherent security flaws.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers and malicious insiders who exploit these vulnerabilities through malware, social engineering, or direct system attacks.

Impacts

The impacts of system vulnerabilities can be severe, including unauthorized data access, system downtime, and compromised data integrity and confidentiality.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker discovers an unpatched vulnerability in an EC2 instances operating system. They exploit this flaw to gain unauthorized access and install ransomware, leading to data encryption and a demand for payment to restore access.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1133 - External Remote Services

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data breach and loss
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Data Breach and Loss in AWS EC2 encompasses unauthorized access and unintended exposure or destruction of data stored on EC2 instances. These incidents can occur due to a variety of security lapses or system failures.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include hackers exploiting security vulnerabilities, insiders abusing their access rights, or accidental exposures due to misconfigurations. Common vectors are compromised credentials, malware, or poorly secured API endpoints.

Impacts

Impacts range from the loss of sensitive or proprietary information to regulatory non-compliance and reputational damage, which can result in significant financial costs.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker uses stolen credentials to access an EC2 instance and exfiltrates databases containing personal customer information, resulting in a data breach that violates privacy laws and leads to financial penalties and loss of customer trust.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1486 - Data Encrypted for Impact

threat.name: Network security issues
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Network security issues in AWS EC2 involve vulnerabilities that affect the network layer, exposing EC2 instances to unauthorized access or data interception. These can result from improper security configurations, weak network protocols, or inadequate encryption practices.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Common agents include external attackers and malicious insiders utilizing tools like packet sniffers, man-in-the-middle attacks, or exploiting public-facing APIs.

Impacts

The impacts include data theft, compromised system integrity, and potential service disruptions, leading to operational and financial losses.

Example Attack Scenarios

An attacker performs a man-in-the-middle attack on unencrypted network communication between EC2 instances, capturing sensitive data transmitted over the network. This breach could result in significant data leakage, including customer information or proprietary business data.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-266
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-266: Incorrect Privilege Assignment A product incorrectly assigns a privilege to a particular actor, creating an unintended sphere of control for that actor.

weakness.name: CWE-311
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-311: Missing Encryption of Sensitive Data The product does not encrypt sensitive or critical information before storage or transmission. The lack of proper data encryption passes up the guarantees of confidentiality, integrity, and accountability that properly implemented encryption conveys.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-500
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-500: Public Static Field Not Marked Final An object contains a public static field that is not marked final, which might allow it to be modified in unexpected ways. Public static variables can be read without an accessor and changed without a mutator by any classes in the application.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Enable audit logs and metrics
countermeasure.desc:
Thoroughly monitor your RDS instances by exporting database logs and OS metrics to CloudWatch Logs, and recording all management API activity via CloudTrail:

  1. Publish database logs to CloudWatch Logs

    • In the RDS console, navigate to Databases [your instance] Modify.
    • Under Log exports, select the general, slow query, and error logs and apply the change.

    • (CLI example):

      aws rds modify-db-instance \

       --db-instance-identifier mydb \

       --cloudwatch-logs-export-configuration '{"EnableLogTypes":["error","general","slowquery"]}' \

       --apply-immediately

    This streams each selected log into its own CloudWatch Logs group for real-time analysis and alerting Documentacin de AWS.

  2. Enable Enhanced Monitoring
    • In the same Modify workflow, under Monitoring, toggle Enable Enhanced Monitoring.
    • Choose a granularity (e.g. 1 s or 15 s) and allow RDS to create or specify the rds-monitoring-role IAM role.
    • Enhanced Monitoring delivers OS-level metrics (CPU, memory, file I/O, etc.) into CloudWatch Logs for deeper visibility Documentacin de AWS.
  3. Capture RDS API activity with CloudTrail
    • Ensure you have a CloudTrail trail that logs management events for all regions.
    • Confirm that Write and Read events for the rds.amazonaws.com service are included.
    • Use the CloudTrail console or Event history to search for RDS API calls (e.g., CreateDBInstance, ModifyDBInstance), capturing who did what and when Documentacin de AWS.

References

  • Logging and monitoring in Amazon RDS (publishing logs & enhanced monitoring)
  • Monitoring Amazon RDS API calls in AWS CloudTrail

countermeasure.name: Enable encryption at rest
countermeasure.desc:
Protect all data at rest in Amazon RDS by leveraging AWS KMS keys (either the AWS-managed aws/rds key or your own customer-managed CMK) to perform AES-256 encryption:

  1. Enable encryption at instance creation
    • When creating a new DB instance (via Console, CLI, or CloudFormation), set Enable encryption to true.
    • In the Encryption section, choose either:
      • AWS managed key (aws/rds) for turnkey management.
      • Customer managed key (specify the KMS key ARN) if you require full control over key rotation and access policies.
    • CLI example:
    • aws rds create-db-instance \
       --db-instance-identifier mydb \
       --engine mysql \
       --allocated-storage 20 \
       --storage-encrypted \
       --kms-key-id arn:aws:kms:us-east-1:123456789012:key/abcd-1234-efgh-5678
  2. Ensure all related resources inherit encryption
    • Automated backups, read replicas, and DB snapshots of an encrypted instance are automatically encrypted with the same KMS key.
    • If you restore from an encrypted snapshot into a new instance, specify the KMS key to maintain encryption.
  3. Manage and audit your keys
    • If using a customer-managed CMK, enable automatic key rotation in the KMS console to rotate the key annually.
    • Use IAM key policies and grants to restrict which principals and roles can use or manage the key.
    • Audit all key usage via AWS CloudTrail to monitor who accessed or decrypted your RDS data Documentacin de AWS.

By enforcing AES-256 encryption with AWS KMSmanaged or customer-managed keys, you ensure that your RDS storage, backups, and replicas remain confidential, tamper-resistant, and compliant with encryption-at-rest requirements.

References

  • Amazon RDS encryption keys (AWS-managed vs. customer-managed)
  • Encryption best practices for Amazon RDS

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS connections
countermeasure.desc:
Encrypt every clientdatabase session and forbid cleartext access by:

  1. Enforce TLS at the engine level
    • PostgreSQL: In your custom parameter group, set rds.force_ssl = 1 and apply it to your instances.
    • MySQL/MariaDB: In your parameter group, set require_secure_transport = ON.
    • SQL Server/Oracle: Use the RDS console or CLI to enable the require SSL option in the instances security settings.
      This ensures the database itself will refuse non-TLS connections Documentacin de AWS.
  2. Distribute and rotate the RDS CA certificates
    • Download the AWS RDS root CA bundle (rds-combined-ca-bundle.pem) from the AWS User Guide.
    • Provision it to your application servers (e.g. via S3, CI/CD pipeline, or configuration management) with appropriate file permissions.
  3. Configure client drivers to use SSL/TLS
    • JDBC (MySQL):
    • jdbc:mysql://mydb.xxxx.region.rds.amazonaws.com:3306/dbname \
       ?useSSL=true \
       &requireSSL=true \
       &verifyServerCertificate=true \
       &trustCertificateKeyStoreUrl=file:/path/to/rds-combined-ca-bundle.pem
    • psql (PostgreSQL):
    • psql "host=mydb.xxxx.region.rds.amazonaws.com port=5432 dbname=mydb \
       sslmode=verify-full \
       sslrootcert=/path/to/rds-combined-ca-bundle.pem"
    • Other drivers: Consult your drivers SSL/TLS configuration options and point them at the RDS CA bundle Documentacin de AWS.
  4. Validate and disable fallback
    • Attempt a connection with SSL disabled (e.g. sslmode=disable or useSSL=false): it must fail.
    • Monitor your RDS instances connections via CloudWatch Metrics (e.g. DatabaseConnections) to confirm only TLS handshakes are occurring.

By enforcing engine-level TLS requirements, distributing AWS-provided certificates, and configuring every client to verify the servers identity, you eliminate unencrypted endpoints and protect data in transit from eavesdropping and tampering.

References

  • Using SSL/TLS to encrypt a connection to a DB instance or cluster
  • Securing connections to RDS for PostgreSQL with SSL/TLS

countermeasure.name: Restrict network access
countermeasure.desc:
Isolate your RDS databases from the public internet and lock down network access by:

  1. Use private subnets for RDS
    • Create or select a DB subnet group that contains only private subnets (no route to an Internet Gateway).
    • When launching or modifying the RDS instance, set Publicly Accessible to No and attach it to this DB subnet group Documentacin de AWS.
  2. Configure security groups
    • Create a dedicated security group for your RDS instance.
    • Add inbound rules that permit only the necessary source CIDR ranges (e.g., your application servers subnets or bastion host IP) on the database port (e.g., TCP 3306 for MySQL).
    • aws ec2 authorize-security-group-ingress \
       --group-id sg-0123456789abcdef0 \
       --protocol tcp \
       --port 3306 \
       --cidr 10.0.1.0/24
    • Do not allow wide-open access (e.g., 0.0.0.0/0).
    • Keep outbound rules minimal (typically allow all or restrict to required management services).
  3. Enforce subnet-level rules with network ACLs
    • Associate a custom network ACL with your private subnets.
    • Define stateless rules that allow only the required traffic and deny everything else:
      • Inbound: Permit TCP on your DB port from your application subnet ranges.
      • Outbound: Permit established response traffic back to those same ranges.
      • Add a deny all rule with a higher rule number to block any other traffic.
    • This adds a second layer of defense at the subnet boundary Documentacin de AWS.

By placing RDS in private subnets, using least-privilege security groups, and applying explicit network ACL rules, you ensure that only authorized hosts and ports can reach your database, reducing attack surface and improving overall network security.

References

  • Amazon VPC and Amazon RDS in a VPC
  • Control subnet traffic with network ACLs

countermeasure.name: Rotate credentials regularly
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure your applications never embed static credentials by centralizing secret storage, automating rotation, and enforcing least-privilege access via IAM roles:

  1. Manage and rotate secrets in AWS Secrets Manager
    • Create a secret for your database credentials in Secrets Manager (e.g. RDS master user or application user).
    • Enable automatic rotation using the built-in RDS rotation Lambda or a custom rotation function. This updates both the secret and the database credentials on a schedule you define (e.g. every 30 days) Documentacin de AWS.
    • Grant your applications EC2 instance profile, ECS task role, or Lambda execution role the secretsmanager:GetSecretValue permission scoped to the secret ARN.
  2. Use SecureString parameters in Systems Manager Parameter Store
    • Store credentials as SecureString parameters encrypted by a KMS key.
    • Automate rotation by invoking a Lambda (via EventBridge) to generate new credentials, update the database, and overwrite the Parameter Store value.
    • Restrict access with an IAM policy granting only ssm:GetParameter (and kms:Decrypt on the KMS key) to the applications IAM role Documentacin de AWS.
  3. Enforce IAM rolebased access
    • Assign a dedicated IAM role to each application component (EC2, ECS, Lambda) that needs database access.
    • Use least-privilege policies that allow only the specific secrets or parameters required, avoiding broad wildcards.
    • Rotate application role credentials via AWS-managed mechanisms (e.g., EC2 Instance Metadata, IAM Roles for Service Accounts) so that no long-lived keys are stored in code or configuration.

By centralizing secrets in managed stores, automating credential rotation, and gating retrieval through narrowly scoped IAM roles, you dramatically reduce the risk of credential leakage and ensure seamless, secure database access.

References

  • Automatic rotation for database secrets in AWS Secrets Manager
  • AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store overview

1.13 - Ensure access keys are rotated every 90 days or less

countermeasure.name: Use least-privilege IAM policies
countermeasure.desc:
Ensure that every IAM role or user interacting with your RDS environment has only the permissions they needand no moreby:

  1. Define minimal, role-specific policies
    • Identify each persona or workload (e.g., application read-only access, backup automation, monitoring, DBA).
    • Write IAM policies granting only the exact RDS (and related) actions required. For example, an application role might need only rds:Connect, rds:DescribeDBInstances, and secretsmanager:GetSecretValue on its credential secret.
    • Scope policies tightly using resource ARNs and, where possible, IAM policy conditions (e.g. source VPC, date/time).
  2. Attach policies to IAM roles
    • Use IAM roles (not long-lived credentials) for EC2, Lambda, ECS tasks, or any service needing RDS access.
    • Avoid embedding AWS credentials in code or environment variables.
  3. Regularly audit and refine permissions
    • Enable IAM Access Analyzer to surface unused access and external sharing in your account. Review its findings and remove any permissions not in active use Documentacin de AWS.
    • Use the IAM consoles Access Advisor (last-accessed information) to detect actions that havent been invoked and tighten policies accordingly.
    • Schedule quarterly reviews of all RDS-related IAM roles and policies, revoking any excessive or stale privileges.

By rigorously applying least-privilege principles and leveraging AWS tools to detect and remove unused permissions, you minimize the blast radius of compromised credentials and adhere to security best practices.

References

  • AWS IAM Security Best Practices (least-privilege guidance)
  • AWS IAM Access Analyzer overview

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Use multi-AZ and automated backups
countermeasure.desc:
Increase resilience and recoverability of your Amazon RDS databases by deploying across Availability Zones, retaining backups, and validating restores:

  1. Enable Multi-AZ deployments
    • When creating or modifying your DB instance, set Multi-AZ deployment to Yes (in the Console), or include:
    • aws rds modify-db-instance \
       --db-instance-identifier mydb \
       --multi-az \
       --apply-immediately
    • This provisions a synchronous standby replica in a different AZ and configures automatic failover Documentacin de AWS.
  2. Configure automated backups and snapshots
    • In the RDS Console under Backup retention, choose a retention period that meets your data retention policy (e.g. 735 days).
    • Ensure Enable automated backups is turned on; RDS will create daily snapshots and capture transaction logs for continuous backup.
    • (CLI example):
    • aws rds modify-db-instance \
       --db-instance-identifier mydb \
       --backup-retention-period 14 \
       --apply-immediately
  3. Test point-in-time recovery (PITR) regularly
    • At least quarterly, perform a restore to a specific point in time:
    • aws rds restore-db-instance-to-point-in-time \
       --source-db-instance-identifier mydb \
       --target-db-instance-identifier mydb-pitr-test \
       --use-latest-restorable-time
    • Validate that the restored instance comes online, that data reflects the intended timestamp, and then clean up the test instance. This confirms your backups and logs are functioning correctly Documentacin de AWS.

By combining Multi-AZ high availability, automated backups with transaction-log retention, and routine PITR drills, you ensure rapid failover, data durability, and verified recovery processes.

References

  • Configuring and managing a Multi-AZ deployment for Amazon RDS
  • Backing up and restoring your Amazon RDS DB instance

reference.name: 2.2.4 - Ensure Multi-AZ deployments are used for enhanced availability in Amazon RDS
3.3 - Ensure AWS Config is enabled in all regions

ID.RA-4: Potential business impacts and likelihoods are identified

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Insufficient backup and recovery
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Insufficient backup and recovery occurs when RDS instances lack properly configured automated snapshots, pointintime restore settings, or cross-region replication. Without reliable backups, data loss and extended outages become unavoidable after failures or deletions.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, malicious insiders, and ransomware operators.
  • Attack Vectors: Misconfigured or disabled automated snapshots; failure to enable Multi-AZ or read-replica backups; absence of cross-region snapshot copy.

Impacts

  • Data Loss: Irrecoverable deletion or corruption of databases.
  • Extended Downtime: Prolonged recovery windows damaging SLAs and productivity.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of retention policies and data-protection regulations.
  • Financial Costs: Emergency restore efforts and potential penalties.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Accidental Deletion: A DBA drops a critical table; no snapshots exist, making recovery impossible.
  2. Ransomware Wipe: Malware gains write access and corrupts the primary DB; without recent backups, data cannot be restored.
  3. Region Outage: A zonal outage destroys the sole RDS instance and its local backups; lack of cross-region copies prevents failover.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1490 - Inhibit System Recovery

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Inadequate IAM permissions
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Misconfigured IAM policies for RDSeither overly permissive or improperly restrictivecan let unauthorized actors perform sensitive database operations or prevent legitimate backups and restores.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM roles, negligent admins
  • Vectors: Wildcard actions (rds:* on *), overly broad principals, conflicting allow/deny rules

Impacts

  • Unauthorized data access, modification, or deletion
  • Data exfiltration or corruption
  • Failed backups/restores and extended downtime
  • Compliance violations (e.g., GDPR, PCI DSS)

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Wildcard Privilege Abuse: An attacker with a compromised role granted rds:* drops production tables and spins up malicious instances.
  2. Public Snapshot Exposure: A service account shares DB snapshots publicly because its IAM policy wasnt scoped to the account.
  3. Backup Failure: A deny rule blocks the rds:CreateDBSnapshot action, causing automated backups to fail during an outage.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unencrypted data transmission
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unencrypted data transmission occurs when RDS database trafficqueries, results, replication streams, or backupsis sent over plaintext channels (e.g., without TLS), allowing anyone intercepting the network to read or tamper with the data in flight.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Network eavesdroppers, MITM attackers, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Connecting to the RDS endpoint over non-TLS ports.
    • Forcing downgrade from TLS to plaintext via misconfigured clients.
    • Intercepting replication or backup traffic on unencrypted channels (e.g. S3 sync without HTTPS).

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Sensitive records (PII, credentials, financial data) can be harvested.
  • Data Tampering: In-flight modification of queries or results can corrupt or redirect data.
  • Session Hijacking: Database session tokens or temporary credentials captured to impersonate applications.
  • Compliance Violations: Transmitting regulated data without encryption breaches standards like PCI DSS, HIPAA, or GDPR.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Client Sniffing: An application connects to RDS over port 3306 without TLS; an attacker on the same network captures SQL traffic and extracts user passwords.
  2. Replication Interception: A read-replica in another region pulls data over an unencrypted channel, and a MITM alters replication events to inject malicious records.
  3. Backup Sync Eavesdrop: Automated backups are pushed to S3 over HTTP; a compromised network node intercepts the transfer and harvests raw database snapshots.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1580 - Cloud Infrastructure Discovery

threat.name: Unencrypted data at rest
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unencrypted data at rest occurs when RDS storage volumesincluding automated snapshots, read replicas, and backupsare not encrypted, leaving all database contents accessible in cleartext.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, external attackers who gain storage access, and third-party service breaches.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Compromised IAM roles or credentials used to download unencrypted snapshots.
    • Unauthorized copying of EBS snapshots or S3-stored backups.
    • Insider misuse of snapshot export or share features to obtain raw data.

Impacts

  • Data Exposure: Sensitive PII, credentials, and business data are readable if storage or backups are exfiltrated.
  • Regulatory Non-Compliance: Violations of mandates like GDPR, HIPAA, or PCI DSS that require encryption at rest.
  • Increased Breach Risk: Easy lateral movement or forensic analysis for attackers who obtain raw storage artifacts.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Snapshot Theft: An attacker compromises an IAM user with permission to copy RDS snapshots, downloads an unencrypted snapshot to S3, and extracts customer records offline.
  2. EBS Volume Access: A malicious admin detaches the underlying unencrypted EBS volume from an RDS instance, attaches it to another host, and mounts it to read all data files directly.
  3. Backup Export Abuse: A disgruntled insider exports automated backups to an external account; since no encryption key is required, they can sieve through sensitive financial or health data at will.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1552.001 - Credentials In Files

threat.name: Excessive network exposure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Excessive network exposure occurs when RDS instances are reachable from broader network ranges than necessarysuch as being publicly accessible or sitting in overly permissive security groupsenabling attackers to connect directly to the database.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, automated scanners, and compromised EC2 instances.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Publicly accessible RDS endpoints (Publicly Accessible = yes).
    • Security groups allowing 0.0.0.0/0 or wide CIDR on port 3306/5432.
    • Missing VPC peering restrictions or network ACLs, permitting lateral movement.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers probe and exploit database vulnerabilities.
  • Data Breach: Exfiltration of sensitive records.
  • Service Disruption: DDoS or brute-force attacks degrade performance.
  • Compliance Violations: Breach of network segmentation requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Public Endpoint Abuse: A database left publicly accessible is discovered by an internet scanner; attacker uses default credentials to dump tables.
  2. Broad SG Rules: A security group opens port 5432 to all IPs; an attacker scripts login attempts until they compromise a privileged account.
  3. Lateral Pivoting: A compromised EC2 in the same VPC but different subnet connects to RDS using permissive network ACLs, then escalates privileges via SQL injection.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Lack of logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When RDS instances lack adequate logging (e.g., disabled audit, error, or slow-query logs) and monitoring (e.g., missing CloudWatch alarms), malicious or accidental activity goes unnoticed, undermining detection, response, and forensic capabilities.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, and automated malware.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Exploiting SQL injection or compromised credentials to modify or exfiltrate data without leaving audit trails.
    • Triggering performance-degrading queries (e.g., Cartesian joins) that go unflagged.
    • Misusing administrative APIs (e.g., snapshot deletion) with no alerting or logs.

Impacts

  • Delayed Detection: Intrusions or misconfigurations persist longer, increasing damage.
  • Forensic Blind Spots: Investigations cant reconstruct events, hindering root-cause analysis.
  • Compliance Failures: Absence of required audit logs breaches standards like PCI DSS or GDPR.
  • Prolonged Outages or Data Loss: Undetected errors or malicious changes lead to extended downtime.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Silent Data Exfiltration: An attacker uses stolen credentials to dump sensitive tables; with audit logging off, no trail exists, delaying discovery for weeks.
  2. Undetected Configuration Change: A rogue insider disables automated backups via the API; without CloudWatch alarms or API-call logs, the change isnt spotted until its too late.
  3. Stealthy Performance Attack: Malware issues heavy, slow queries that degrade database performance; absent slow-query logs and alarms, the performance drop is attributed to normal load until the service fails.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1070.001 - Clear Windows Event Logs

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Weak credential management
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Weak credential management occurs when database credentialssuch as usernames, passwords, or IAM authentication tokensare handled insecurely (e.g. hard-coded, stored in plaintext, or not rotated), making them easy to discover or reuse.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious outsiders, compromised automation tools, and negligent insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Leaking credentials in source code repositories or container images.
    • Retrieving IAM-based database tokens from instance metadata with overly broad role permissions.
    • Exploiting exposed parameters in unencrypted Parameter Store or Secrets Manager entries.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Attackers use stolen credentials to connect directly to the database.
  • Data Breach: Confidential records can be read, modified, or deleted.
  • Privilege Escalation: Compromised credentials may grant elevated privileges or access to other services.
  • Operational Disruption: Credential misuse can lead to denial of service or forced credential rotation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Code Commit Leak: A developer inadvertently commits db_password in application.properties to GitHub; attackers clone the repo and authenticate to the RDS instance.
  2. Metadata API Abuse: An EC2 instance role with rds-db:connect permission is compromised; an attacker queries the metadata endpoint for IAM tokens and accesses the database.
  3. Unencrypted Secret Retrieval: Credentials stored in plain-text in AWS Systems Manager Parameter Store are retrieved by any user with read permissions, allowing unauthorized database connections.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-295
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-295: Improper Certificate Validation The product does not validate, or incorrectly validates, a certificate. When a certificate is invalid or malicious, it might allow an attacker to spoof a trusted entity by interfering in the communication path between the host and client. The product might connect to a malicious host while believing it is a trusted host, or the product might be deceived into accepting spoofed data that appears to originate from a trusted host.

weakness.name: CWE-349
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-349: Acceptance of Extraneous Untrusted Data With Trusted Data The product, when processing trusted data, accepts any untrusted data that is also included with the trusted data, treating the untrusted data as if it were trusted.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-358
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-358: Improperly Implemented Security Check for Standard The product does not implement or incorrectly implements one or more security-relevant checks as specified by the design of a standardized algorithm, protocol, or technique.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-408
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-408: Incorrect Behavior Order: Early Amplification The product allows an entity to perform a legitimate but expensive operation before authentication or authorization has taken place.

weakness.name: CWE-663
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-663: Use of a Non-reentrant Function in a Concurrent Context The product calls a non-reentrant function in a concurrent context in which a competing code sequence (e.g. thread or signal handler) may have an opportunity to call the same function or otherwise influence its state.

weakness.name: CWE-697
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-697: Incorrect Comparison The product compares two entities in a security-relevant context, but the comparison is incorrect, which may lead to resultant weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-710
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-710: Improper Adherence to Coding Standards The product does not follow certain coding rules for development, which can lead to resultant weaknesses or increase the severity of the associated vulnerabilities.

countermeasure.name: Apply least-privilege stateful security group rules
countermeasure.desc:
Define inbound and outbound security-group (SG) rules so that every AWS workload can send or receive traffic only on the protocols and ports it actually uses, nothing more. Because SGs are statefulreturn traffic is automatically allowedyou do not need mirror rules; focus on the direction that initiates the flow.

Implementation guidance

  1. Map the traffic flows for each component (for Route 53 Resolver endpoints that means UDP/TCP 53, for web apps TCP 80/443, etc.).
  2. Create one SG per role (e.g., resolver-inbound, web-front, db-backend).
  3. Ingress rules
    • Allow only the required protocol/port combination from the smallest possible CIDR or, preferably, from another SG (for east-west traffic).
    • Block 0.0.0.0/0 and ::/0 unless there is a documented business reason.
  4. Egress rules
    • Remove the default allow all; add explicit destinations and ports (for example, TCP 443 to a patch repository).
    • Remember: responses to permitted ingress traffic do not need additional egress rules thanks to SG statefulness.
  5. Automation & guardrails
    • Bake SGs into CloudFormation/Terraform modules; lint templates for wild-card CIDRs or open ports.
    • Enable AWS Config managed rules such as restricted-common-ports or custom rules that fail a build when an SG exposes SSH/RDP/DB ports to the internet.
    • Use VPC Flow Logs and Reachability Analyzer to validate that only intended paths succeed.
  6. Continuous review
    • Periodically audit SGs with Security Hub; prune stale or unused rules.
    • When requirements change (for example, adding DNS over TLS on port 853), update the SGs in IaC first, then deploy.

Following a least-privilege, stateful-aware model minimizes the attack surface, avoids duplicate rules, and keeps network intent clear and enforceable.

references

  • Security groups connection tracking
  • Restrict incoming traffic to only authorized ports AWS Prescriptive Guidance

countermeasure.name: Create inbound Resolver endpoints across multiple AZs
countermeasure.desc:
Provision every Route 53 Resolver inbound endpoint with at least two IP addresses, each in a different Availability Zone (AZ) of the VPC. Route 53 maps every IP to an elastic network interface (ENI), so distributing them across AZ-scoped subnets ensures that DNS resolution continues even if an AZ, subnet, or ENI is impaired.

Implementation checklist

  1. Subnet planning Identify two or more private subnets in distinct AZs that have outbound routes to your on-premises network (via Direct Connect or VPN).
  2. Endpoint creation In the Route 53 console, choose Inbound endpoints Create inbound endpoint, then add one IP per chosen subnet. Repeat until you have a minimum of two IP addresses.
  3. Security groups Attach a security group that allows inbound UDP/TCP 53 from the IP ranges of your on-premises DNS resolvers.
  4. Forwarding configuration Configure each on-premises resolver to forward queries to all endpoint IPs (round-robin or equal-cost) so fail-over happens automatically.
  5. Monitoring & drift control
    • Enable Route 53 Resolver query logging and CloudWatch metrics (e.g., DnsQueries, DnsResolverEndpointMetricName).
    • Deploy an AWS Config rule or IaC linter that fails if an inbound endpoint has fewer than two IPs or all IPs reside in one AZ.
  6. Capacity events & maintenance Add a third IP (in a third AZ if available) when traffic or resiliency requirements grow; remove only after confirming redundancy.

Following this pattern eliminates the single-AZ single-ENI failure mode and aligns with AWS best-practice guidance for high-availability DNS ingress.

references

  • High availability for Resolver endpoints Amazon Route 53 Developer Guide
  • Best practices for Resolver Amazon Route 53 Developer Guide

standard.ref: DE.CM-1: The network is monitored to detect potential cybersecurity events
PR.DS-4: Adequate capacity to ensure availability is maintained
PR.PT-4: Communications and control networks are protected

countermeasure.name: Define default record in each geolocation, geoproximity, and latency policy
countermeasure.desc:
For every Route 53 record set that uses geolocation, geoproximity, or latency-based routing, create a catch-all (default) record so that any query that doesnt match a specific location, bias shape, or Region still receives a valid answer instead of a NOERROR NODATA response.

Implementation steps

  1. Geolocation records Add one extra record whose Location is set to Default. This record answers:
    • IP addresses that Route 53 cannot map to a geography.
    • Countries, continents, or subdivisions for which you have not created explicit records.
  2. Geoproximity records Create a record that covers the entire globe by leaving the bias at 0 and not restricting the AWS Region or endpoint. (Alternatively, add a parallel simple record with the same name to act as the fallback.)
  3. Latency-based records Include at least one latency record that points to a universally acceptable Region (for example, the Region hosting your primary stack). If all health-checked latency records become UNHEALTHY, pair the default record with a failover standby or a health check that keeps it available.
  4. Validation Use dig +trace or Resolver Query Logging to confirm that queries from out-of-scope locations resolve to the default answer.
  5. Automation & drift detection Add a CI/CD test or AWS Config custom rule that fails a deployment if an advanced routing set (geo*, latency) lacks at least one default record. Review routing policies quarterly as new Regions or markets go live.

Having a default record guarantees that every DNS question receives an authoritative response, preventing unnecessary retransmits, resolver fall-back to TCP, and user-visible outages.

references

  • Geolocation routing
  • Values specific for geolocation records

countermeasure.name: Delegate subdomains from the immediate parent hosted zone
countermeasure.desc:
For every subdomain that you manage in Amazon Route 53, create a dedicated hosted zone for that subdomain and publish an NS record set in the parent hosted zone that points to the name servers assigned to the child zone. Never skip a level (for example, delegate api.dev.example.com directly from example.com); each child zone must be delegated by its immediate parent to guarantee that recursive resolvers can follow the hierarchy without ambiguity or cache inconsistencies.

Implementation steps

  1. Create the child hosted zone (e.g., dev.example.com) and note the four authoritative name-server values that Route 53 returns.
  2. In the parent hosted zone (e.g., example.com), add an NS record named exactly like the subdomain ( dev.example.com ) that lists those four name servers. Keep the TTL short (300 s900 s) while you validate, then raise it when stable.
  3. (Optional but recommended) add a matching SOA record in the child zone to aid debugging and DNSSEC deployments.
  4. Enforce the rule in infrastructure-as-code: have a linter or CI/CD test that fails if a hosted zones domain cannot be found as an NS record in its parent.
  5. Monitor with Route 53 Resolver Query Logging or a custom AWS Config rule to alert on missing or mismatched NS delegations.

Correct, explicit delegation at each level ensures consistent name resolution, avoids ghost zones that some resolvers cache, and lets you move subdomain ownership or accounts safely without touching the apex domain.

references

  • Routing traffic for subdomains
  • Best practices for Amazon Route 53

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1048 - Application Isolation and Sandboxing

countermeasure.name: Implement comprehensive health check strategy
countermeasure.desc:
Create an Amazon Route 53 health-monitoring stack that automatically detects outages, triggers alerts, and shifts traffic away from unhealthy endpoints:

  1. Stable targets. Point each health check at an Elastic IP (EIP) or other static address (for ALB/NLB use their DNS name) so the target doesnt change when an instance is replaced. Deleteor re-pointchecks whenever the underlying resource is retired.
  2. Intervals & thresholds.
    • Start with the 30 s default; reduce to 10 s for customer-facing or transactional services that require rapid failover.
    • Set the failure threshold to 35 consecutive probes; decrease (12) for aggressive failover or increase (610) if flapping is a concern.
  3. Multi-region checkers. Enable Evaluate target health in multiple regions so that decisions arent skewed by a single checker outage.
  4. CloudWatch integration. Route 53 publishes a HealthCheckStatus metric for every check. Create a CloudWatch alarm that fires when the status equals 0 for 1 datapoint, and wire it to an SNS topic, PagerDuty, or Slack webhook.
  5. Routing & failover policies.
    • Attach the health check to the primary DNS record in a Failover or Multivalue routing policy.
    • Define one or more standby records (different EIP, Region, or AWS account) that become authoritative when the primary is marked UNHEALTHY. Validate that clients resolve the standby within your records TTL.
  6. Continuous monitoring.
    • Enable Route 53 query logging and review CloudWatch metrics weekly; look for rising latency or sporadic failures.
    • Schedule a quarterly runbook review: verify EIPs are current, intervals/thresholds match SLOs, alarms reach the right on-call rotation, and failover actually occurs during a game-day test.
  7. Guardrails & automation.
    • Store health checks, alarms, and DNS records in CloudFormation/Terraform modules.
    • Add a CI/CD lint rule (or AWS Config custom rule) that fails a build if a health check:
      • Lacks an alarm,
      • Uses an interval > 30 s for a critical service, or
      • Evaluates in fewer than two AWS regions.

Following these steps ensures that health monitoring is consistent, fast, and actionable, while automatic DNS failover keeps endpoints available during incidents.

References

  • Best practices for Amazon Route 53 health checks
  • Monitoring health checks with CloudWatch Route 53 Developer Guide

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

countermeasure.name: Monitor abnormal DNS query patterns and escalate potential zone-walking
countermeasure.desc:
Enable continuous visibility into the DNS traffic that Amazon Route 53 handles for your accounts and take action when activity suggests a zone-walking attack (rapid, exhaustive queries across a zone that trigger Resolver throttling):

  1. Capture the data
    • Turn on Route 53 Resolver query logging (or public-hosted-zone query logging) and stream logs to CloudWatch Logs, S3, or Firehose for retention and analysis.
    • Track CloudWatch metrics such as DNSQueries, DnsResolverQueries, and (for Resolver endpoints) ConnectionTrackingDroppedQueries.
  2. Baseline normal behaviour
    • Use CloudWatch Metric Math or Anomaly Detection to learn typical query-per-second (QPS) levels and NXDOMAIN ratios for each hosted zone or VPC.
    • Flag sudden spikes, a surge in unique subdomain labels, or high NXDOMAIN countscommon signatures of enumeration tools.
  3. Alert on suspected attacks
    • Create metric filters or Lambda log analytics that detect:
      • X % NXDOMAIN or SERVFAIL responses over Y minutes.
      • Sequential queries that iterate through the alphabet or numeric ranges.
      • Resolver logs showing THROTTLED responses.
    • Wire alarms to an on-call channel (SNS PagerDuty/Slack) so investigation starts immediately.
  4. Escalate when throttling appears
    • If queries begin timing out and logs show throttling yet the traffic is legitimate, open an AWS Support case citing the affected Resolver endpoint IDs and timestamps. The Route 53 team can confirm throttling heuristics and restore capacity if appropriate.
  5. Harden and review
    • Apply DNS Firewall rules or upstream ACLs to block abusive source ranges.
    • Review baselines and alarm thresholds quarterly; update detection logic as traffic patterns evolve.

Following this workflow ensures that potential zone-walking attempts are detected quickly, legitimate traffic is restored, and AWS is engaged when throttling impacts availability.

References:

  • DNS zone walking

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1057 - Data Loss Prevention

countermeasure.name: Poll GetChange until change is INSYNC before next deployment step
countermeasure.desc:
When your pipeline submits a ChangeResourceRecordSets, ChangeTagsForResource, or CreateHostedZone request, Route 53 returns a change ID. Automate a loop that calls GetChange <change-id> every few seconds and proceeds only when the response field Status == INSYNC. This guarantees that the update has propagated to every Route 53 authoritative name server before later stagessuch as health checks, load-balancer swaps, or traffic-shift testsrun.

Implementation tips

  1. Loop with back-off

    1. while true; do
       status=$(aws route53 get-change --id "$CHANGE_ID" --query 'ChangeInfo.Status' --output text)
       [ "$status" = "INSYNC" ] && break
       sleep 5   # or exponential back-off capped at 30 s
      done 

    In IaC tools (CloudFormation, Terraform) or CD frameworks (CodePipeline, GitHub Actions), wrap the check in a retry helper so failures surface clearly.

  2. Timeout and alerting
    • Set a max wait (e.g., 5 min); raise an alarm or fail the job if the change never becomes INSYNC.
    • Send the failure to an on-call channel via SNS so someone can investigate Route 53 control-plane health.
  3. Parallelism
    If you batch multiple changes, store each change ID and poll them in parallel to shorten overall deploy time, but make sure all return INSYNC before continuing.
  4. Idempotency & cleanup
    Handle interrupted runs by reading any existing change ID from state storage (S3, DynamoDB) so reruns dont create duplicate batches.
  5. Testing & CI linting
    Add unit tests that mock GetChange responses to validate your wait-logic. In integration environments, inject deliberate delays to ensure the loop tolerates long propagation times.
  6. Documentation comments
    Inline code comments should note that INSYNC means full global propagation and that skipping the wait can cause stale DNS answers during traffic-shift or health-check stages.

This control removes race conditions caused by Route 53s eventual consistency and ensures each deployment step operates on authoritative, up-to-date DNS data.

References

  • Amazon Route 53 API Reference
  • Route 53 DNS best practices

countermeasure.name: Prevent VPC loop by separating Resolver rule and inbound endpoint associations
countermeasure.desc:
Never associate the same VPC with both (a) a Route 53 Resolver inbound endpoint and (b) a forwarding (outbound) Resolver rule that targets that endpoint. Doing so creates a circular DNS pathqueries leave the VPC through the rule, hit the inbound endpoint in the very same VPC, and bounce indefinitely until Resolver throttles them.

Implementation guidance

  1. Design the topology
    • Host inbound endpoints in a dedicated DNS-VPC.
    • Keep forwarding rules in other VPCs that need to query the inbound endpoint.
  2. Share rules safely
    • Use AWS Resource Access Manager (AWS RAM) to share the forwarding rules with spoke VPCs or accounts instead of associating them directly to the DNS-VPC.
  3. Create and associate resources

aws route53resolver create-resolver-endpoint --creator-request-id dns-ep \
   --direction INBOUND --ip-addresses SubnetId=subnet-a,Ip=10.0.1.10 SubnetId=subnet-b,Ip=10.0.2.10

aws route53resolver create-resolver-rule --creator-request-id fwd-rule \
   --rule-type FORWARD --domain-name corp.example.com \
   --target-ips Ip=10.0.1.10,Port=53 Ip=10.0.2.10,Port=53
 

  • Do not run associate-resolver-rule with the DNS-VPC ID; instead associate it with each spoke VPC (or share via RAM).
  1. Validate
    • Run list-resolver-rule-associations daily (or an AWS Config custom rule) to flag any VPC that shows up in both an inbound endpoint and the rule it forwards to.
    • Watch Resolver CloudWatch metrics for sudden spikes in DroppedQueries or ServFailpossible signs of a loop.
  2. Operational review
    • Re-confirm associations after every VPC peering, AWS RAM share, or network change.
    • Document the pattern in your IaC modules so reviews and automated tests catch mis-associations before deployment.

Following this pattern eliminates routing loops, preserves Resolver capacity, and lets you centralize DNS services without compromising VPC isolation.

References

  • Avoid loop configurations with Resolver endpoints
  • Best practices for Resolver

countermeasure.name: Set Route 53 record TTLs based on record stability
countermeasure.desc:
Configure the TTL (time-to-live) of every Amazon Route 53 DNS record so that it falls between 60 s and 172 800 s (1 min48 h), choosing the value according to how often the record is expected to change:

  1. Dynamic or health-checked records (failover, latency, geoproximity, weighted, alias with health checks).
    • Set TTL to 60120 s so that resolvers refresh quickly after a failover event or an automated change.
  2. Static or rarely changing records (static web sites, mail servers, alias to CloudFront/S3, etc.).
    • Use a longer TTL 3 600 s up to 172 800 sto improve resolver-side caching, lower query volume, and reduce cost.
  3. Planned changes (IP migration, provider cut-over, major DNS re-architecture).
    • 4872 h before the change, temporarily lower TTL to ~60 s for the affected records so that caches age out before the cut-over.
    • Perform and verify the change.
    • Restore the original longer TTL once the new configuration is stable (typically a few hours after validation).

Automate the rule in infrastructure-as-code templates (CloudFormation/Terraform) or CI/CD linting so any TTL outside the allowed range triggers a build failure. Add CloudWatch metrics or Config Rules to alert on TTL drift.

References

  • Best practices for Amazon Route 53 DNS Documentacin de AWS
  • DNS best practices for Amazon Route 53

countermeasure.name: Use multivalue answer routing to limit DNS response size
countermeasure.desc:
Configure DNS records that have many endpoints (for example, multiple web-server IPs) as multivalue answer routing records in Amazon Route 53. Multivalue answer routing returns a random subset of up to eight healthy records, which keeps typical UDP responses below the 512-byte limit defined in the DNS specification and avoids packet truncation or forced TCP retries.

Implementation steps

  1. Identify large record sets Any A, AAAA, or CNAME record whose wire-format size could exceed 512 bytes ( >25 IPv4 or >10 IPv6 addresses) is a candidate.
  2. Create multivalue answer records In the Route 53 console or IaC template, choose Multivalue answer and list every endpoint value. Attachor reuseRoute 53 health checks so only healthy targets are served.
  3. Validate size Use dig +bufsize=512 <name> or dnsperf against the public resolver to confirm that the UDP answer flag TC=0 (not truncated).
  4. Tune TTL and health-check settings Set TTL to 60300 s for volatile pools; 300900 s for stable pools. Keep health-check interval at 30 s (or 10 s for critical services) with a failure threshold of 35 probes.
  5. Monitor and alert Enable Route 53 query logging and CloudWatch metrics (DNSQueries, HealthCheckStatus). Add a CloudWatch alarm that fires when health checks fail or query errors rise.
  6. Automate enforcement Add an AWS Config custom rule or CI/CD linter that fails a deployment if:
    • Record type is Simple and size estimate > 512 bytes, or
    • Multivalue record has no health check.
  7. Periodic review Quarterly, recalculate record size after adding or retiring endpoints, and rerun validation tests. Update health-check targets and TTLs as architecture evolves.

Following this approach keeps DNS responses lightweight and standards-compliant while still providing high availability through health-checked, randomly rotated answers.

references

  • Multivalue answer routing returns up to eight healthy records
  • DNS responses over UDP are limited to 512 bytes

countermeasure.name: Use Route 53 alias records instead of CNAMEs for AWS and same-zone targets
countermeasure.desc:
Replace every CNAME that points to an AWS-managed resource (CloudFront, S3 website endpoint, ELB/NLB, API Gateway, CloudFront, VPC interface endpoint, etc.) or to another record in the same hosted zonewith a Route 53 alias A/AAAA record. Alias records are resolved directly by Route 53, so clients receive the final A/AAAA answer in a single round-trip, which lowers latency, eliminates an extra lookup for the CNAME target, works at the zone apex (where CNAMEs are illegal), and incurs no query charges.

Implementation steps

  1. Inventory candidates
    • Run aws route53 list-resource-record-sets --hosted-zone-id Z123 or parse your IaC templates to find CNAME records.
    • Flag any CNAME whose value ends in amazonaws.com or whose target domain is inside the same hosted zone.
  2. Create the alias record
    • Console: Type A (or AAAA for IPv6) Alias Yes Alias target select the AWS resource or Alias to another record in this zone.
    • IaC example (CloudFormation):
    • RootAlias:
       Type: AWS::Route53::RecordSet
       Properties:
         HostedZoneName: example.com.
         Name: example.com.
         Type: A
         AliasTarget:
           HostedZoneId: !GetAtt MyLoadBalancer.CanonicalHostedZoneID
           DNSName: !GetAtt MyLoadBalancer.DNSName
    • Enable EvaluateTargetHealth when the target supports health checks (ELB, CloudFront).
  3. Retire the CNAME Delete or comment out the old record to prevent conflicts.
  4. Validate resolution dig +nocmd example.com A +short should now return IPs directly; no CNAME line appears.
  5. Automate enforcement
    • Add a linter or AWS Config custom rule that fails a commit if it introduces a CNAME whose target ends with amazonaws.com or matches the hosted-zone domain.
    • Include a unit test in your pipeline that runs list-resource-record-sets and asserts zero such CNAMEs.
  6. Periodic review Re-run the inventory quarterly or whenever new AWS services are introduced, ensuring new endpoints use alias records by default.

This control shortens DNS resolution time, removes the apex-record limitation, and cuts Route 53 query costs while keeping your zone files cleaner and easier to audit.

references

  • Choosing between alias and non-alias records
  • How to create alias records for AWS services
