usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Oversized DNS responses
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Oversized DNS responses occur when Route 53 returns records so largedue to extensive RRsets, DNSSEC signatures, or long TXT entriesthat they exceed typical UDP size limits or require fragmentation, leading to resolution failures or enabling amplification attacks.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, misconfigured DNS administrators, and automated scanners.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Publishing very large TXT/SPF/DMARC records or including DNSSEC RRSIGs without adequate size controls.
    • Crafting DNS queries (e.g. ANY or EDNS options) that force Route 53 to return the full record set.
    • Exploiting the large responses for DNS amplification by spoofing victim IPs.

Impacts

  • Resolution Failures: Fragmented or truncated UDP responses may be dropped by resolvers or firewalls, causing lookup timeouts.
  • DoS on Resolvers: Large or fragmented packets consume bandwidth and CPU on recursive resolvers or clients.
  • Amplification Attacks: Attackers leverage the size disparity between small queries and large responses to flood victims with DNS traffic.
  • Increased Latency: Even successful TCP fallback queries incur delays, degrading application performance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. TXT Record Bloat: A domain owner publishes an excessively long SPF record (>4 KB). Many recursive resolvers truncate the UDP response, leading to email delivery failures.
  2. DNSSEC Overhead: Enabling DNSSEC on a busy zone without size tuning causes RRSIGs to bloat responses; firewalls block fragmented packets, making the domain unreachable.
  3. Reflection Amplification: An attacker sends forged ANY queries to Route 53 for a zone with hundreds of A records, causing large UDP replies to flood a victims IP, overwhelming their network.

threat.name: Routing loop configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Routing loop configurations occur when DNS records unintentionally refer queries in a circular mannersuch as CNAMEs pointing at each other or alias records cascading between zonescausing resolvers to loop indefinitely rather than resolve to an endpoint.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, misconfigured automation scripts, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Creating CNAME records that point at each other (A B, B A).
    • Alias (ALIAS/ANAME) records across hosted zones that redirect back in a circle.
    • Scripting zone updates without detecting circular dependencies.

Impacts

  • Resolution Failures: Clients receive SERVFAIL or timeout after exhausting DNS retries.
  • Service Outages: Applications and APIs become unreachable due to broken name resolution.
  • Increased Latency & Load: Resolvers and authoritative servers waste cycles chasing loops, degrading performance.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Accidental CNAME Loop: An admin adds app.example.com api.example.com and api.example.com app.example.com, causing every lookup to loop until timeouts.
  2. Cross-Zone Alias Loop: A GeoDNS policy points eu.example.com as an alias to us.example.com, and vice versa for us.example.com, preventing traffic from ever resolving.
  3. Malicious Automation: A compromised CI/CD job injects circular alias records into multiple zones, creating widespread DNS failures across services.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

threat.name: Improper DNS delegation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Improper DNS delegation occurs when a zone or subdomains NS records point to incorrect, outdated, or attacker-controlled name servers. This misconfiguration lets malicious parties answer DNS queries for that domain, enabling spoofing, subdomain takeover, or traffic hijacking.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, and negligent administrators.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Delegating a subdomain to name servers under attacker control.
    • Failing to update NS records after migrating DNS zones, leaving stale delegations.
    • Omitting glue records for child zones, causing resolvers to fall back to rogue servers.

Impacts

  • Traffic Hijacking: Users and services resolve to malicious endpoints.
  • Subdomain Takeover: Attackers serve content or APIs under your namespace.
  • Phishing & Data Theft: Malicious sites impersonate legitimate services.
  • Service Disruption: Legitimate DNS responses are blocked or misrouted, causing downtime.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Attacker-Controlled NS: A subdomain api.example.com is delegated to NS records at ns1.evil.com. The attacker runs ns1.evil.com, resolving api.example.com to their server and intercepting API traffic.
  2. Stale Delegation: After moving blog.example.com to a new DNS provider, the old NS entries remain published. An attacker registers the old providers account and takes over the subdomain.
  3. Missing Glue Records: A child zone dev.example.com lacks glue records at the parent. Resolvers fall back to arbitrary servers that response with malicious IPs, redirecting development traffic to fake resources.

threat.name: Health check misconfigurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Misconfigured health checkssuch as incorrect endpoints, overly strict thresholds, or wrong protocolscan cause Route 53 to mark healthy resources as unhealthy (or vice versa), leading to unintended traffic routing or failover.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Negligent administrators, automation errors, and external attackers.
  • Vectors:
    • Pointing health checks at wrong paths or ports.
    • Setting aggressive failure thresholds or unreasonably low intervals.
    • Using HTTP checks against services that require HTTPS or custom headers.

Impacts

  • Unplanned Failover: Healthy endpoints are bypassed, routing traffic to under-provisioned backups.
  • Service Flapping: Transient errors trigger frequent DNS updates, causing resolution instability.
  • Extended Outages: False unhealthy states prevent traffic to available resources, increasing downtime.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Path Mismatch: A health check targets /healthz but the service uses /status; Route 53 flags the primary as down and shifts traffic to an overloaded secondary.
  2. Threshold Abuse: An attacker induces brief spikes in response time; overly strict failure settings mark the endpoint unhealthy, triggering unwanted failover.
  3. Protocol Error: A check is configured as HTTP on an HTTPS-only service, causing constant failures and DNS flapping between records.

threat.name: Single-AZ resolver endpoint
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A single-AZ Route 53 Resolver endpoint creates a single point of failure: if that Availability Zone experiences an outage or network disruption, DNS resolution for dependent resources breaks.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: AWS infrastructure failures, network disruptions, and targeted DDoS against the AZ.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • AZ-wide power or network outage taking the resolver endpoint offline.
    • Saturation of the resolvers network interface via volumetric DNS floods.
    • Misconfiguration that routes all DNS traffic to the lone endpoint.

Impacts

  • Resolution Failure: EC2 instances and on-premise networks using the resolver lose name resolution.
  • Service Disruption: Applications dependent on internal DNS (service discovery, authentication) may fail.
  • Operational Risk: Teams cannot troubleshoot or apply fixes if DNS queries timeout.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. AZ Outage: A power fault knocks out the single resolver endpoint in us-east-1a, leaving downstream services unable to resolve database hostnames.
  2. Targeted DNS Flood: An attacker floods the resolvers ENI with spoofed DNS queries, saturating its capacity and causing legitimate lookups to drop.
  3. Misrouted Traffic: A VPC peering update accidentally directs all DNS queries to the lone resolver in one AZ, so when that AZs network ACL is changed, resolution across the VPC grid fails.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Unoptimized resolver security groups
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unoptimized Resolver security groups occur when the AWS Route 53 Resolver endpoints are placed in security groups with overly permissive rules or missing necessary restrictions, exposing DNS resolution traffic to unauthorized sources or destinations.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, malicious insiders, and compromised EC2 instances.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Ingress rules allowing UDP/TCP 53 from any IP (0.0.0.0/0), letting outsiders query or poison internal DNS.
    • Egress rules permitting unrestricted outbound DNS, enabling malware to exfiltrate data via DNS tunnels.
    • Lack of network-level separation between resolver endpoints and untrusted subnets or VPCs.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized DNS Queries: Attackers can enumerate internal hostnames or poison caches.
  • Data Exfiltration: Malicious payloads hidden in DNS requests/responses.
  • Service Disruption: Flooding or spoofing attacks against the resolver degrade or halt name resolution.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromised hosts use open resolver rules to move across network segments.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open UDP 53 Ingress: A security group allows DNS queries from the Internet; an attacker routinely queries internal services, mapping out infrastructure.
  2. Unrestricted Egress for Tunneling: Malware on an EC2 spins up DNS tunneling over the resolvers egress port to exfiltrate confidential data.
  3. Cross-VPC Misrouting: A shared security group between public and private subnets lets a public-facing instance inject poisoned responses into the resolver, corrupting name resolution for all private workloads.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1048 - Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol

threat.name: DNS TTL misconfiguration
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Misconfigured DNS TTLseither set too high or too lowcan delay record updates or overwhelm resolvers with excessive queries, hindering failover agility and service performance.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Negligent administrators and external attackers.
  • Vectors:
    • High TTLs prolong caching of outdated or poisoned records.
    • Low TTLs trigger surges of recursive lookups, straining DNS infrastructure.

Impacts

  • Extended Outages: Legitimate DNS changes (e.g., failover) dont propagate until TTL expiry.
  • Performance Degradation & Cost Spikes: Flooded resolvers and Route 53 query charges rise sharply.
  • Stale or Poisoned Caches: Attackers spoofed records persist longer under long TTLs.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Stale Endpoint: A 24-hour TTL keeps users pointing at a compromised IP for a full day after a breach.
  2. Resolver Overload: A 5-second TTL in production triggers millions of lookups per minute, throttling DNS services.
  3. Cache Poisoning: During a lookup, an attacker injects a fake record; a 12-hour TTL lets the malicious entry persist across client caches.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

threat.name: Suboptimal alias record usage
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Suboptimal alias record usage occurs when Route 53 alias records are configured without appropriate health checks, routing policies, or alignment with the underlying resources availability zones. This can lead to stale DNS mappings, unexpected failover behavior, or dependency on single points of failure.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, misconfigured automation, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Pointing an alias to a resource (e.g. ELB, CloudFront) without enabling health checks, so DNS never updates when the target fails.
    • Using a simple alias for cross-account or cross-region resources without proper routing policies, leading to stale caches.
    • Automating alias updates via scripts that fail silently, leaving outdated records in place.

Impacts

  • Extended Outages: Clients continue resolving to unhealthy endpoints, delaying failover.
  • Traffic Misrouting: Requests sent to decommissioned or wrong resources.
  • Operational Complexity: Difficult to audit and maintain alias targets, increasing error rates and MTTR.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Health-Check Omission: An alias api.example.com points to an ELB but lacks a linked health check; when the ELB goes down, traffic isnt rerouted to the standby, causing sustained downtime.
  2. Cross-Region Staleness: A dev team aliases db.example.com to a read-replica in another region for DR testing without weighted routing; DNS caches remain pointed at the DR instance even after failback.
  3. Automation Glitch: A CI/CD job updates an alias following deployment but the scripts IAM role lacks permission to change records; the old alias persists, sending users to an outdated backend.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1570 - Lateral Tool Transfer

threat.name: Missing default routing policy
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When no default routing record is defined (e.g. in geolocation, latency, or weighted policies), queries that dont match any specific rule return NXDOMAIN, causing legitimate users to be unable to resolve the domain.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Agents: Negligent administrators, misconfigured automation, and Puppet/CloudFormation bugs.
  • Vectors: Deploying geolocation or weighted policies without an all-other or default record; removing a catch-all record during updates.

Impacts

  • Partial Outages: Users in unhandled regions or error cases see DNS failures.
  • Lost Traffic & Revenue: Inaccessible services for subsets of clients.
  • Increased Support Load: Spike in help-desk tickets and incident investigations.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Geolocation Gap: A site configures geolocation records for US and APAC but omits default. Users in Europe get NXDOMAIN and cannot reach the service.
  2. Weighted Misfire: Two weighted records exist at 50/50, but no default. During weighted evaluation errors, some queries fall through and fail, degrading availability.
  3. Failover Slip-Through: Primary and secondary failover records exist, but without a default, health-check misfires send traffic to nowhere, causing full DNS resolution failures.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1071 - Application Layer Protocol

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: DNS zone walking attacks
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
DNS zone walking attacks allow adversaries to enumerate all DNS records in a hosted zoneeither by abusing misconfigured zone transfers (AXFR/IXFR) or leveraging DNSSEC NSEC/NSEC3 responsesrevealing the full namespace and infrastructure details.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, automated reconnaissance tools, and malicious insiders.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Unauthorized AXFR/IXFR zone transfers due to lax ACLs on the Route 53 delegation.
    • Iterative DNSSEC NSEC/NSEC3 record traversal to list all names in a signed zone.
    • Abuse of wildcard or catch-all records that leak subdomain structures.

Impacts

  • Infrastructure Reconnaissance: Full visibility into hostnames, subdomains, and service endpoints.
  • Targeted Attack Facilitation: Enables precise phishing, vulnerability scanning, or lateral-movement planning.
  • Subdomain Takeover Risk: Identifies unused or delegatable subdomains ripe for takeover.
  • Privacy & Compliance Exposure: Disclosure of internal service names or project identifiers.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Unrestricted Zone Transfer: An attacker issues an AXFR request against the NS records for corp.example.com and retrieves the entire record set, mapping internal mail, VPN, and API hosts.
  2. DNSSEC Enumeration: Despite disabled AXFR, the zone is DNSSEC-signed; the adversary uses NSEC records to walk the namespace, listing every *.dev.example.com and planning targeted exploits.
  3. Wildcard Leakage: A catch-all record (*.staging.example.com) inadvertently exposes subdomain names when queried, allowing attackers to discover forgotten test environments.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1590 - Gather Victim Network Information

threat.name: Unverified DNS change propagation
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Unverified DNS change propagation occurs when updates to hosted zone records are assumed successful without validating that changes have correctly propagated to all DNS caches and resolvers. This can leave stale or malicious records in use, causing traffic misrouting or persistent vulnerabilities.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Negligent administrators, malicious insiders, automation tools, and external attackers.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Failing to verify DNS record updates across geographic or ISP caches.
    • Automation scripts that push changes without post-deployment checks.
    • Attackers exploiting cached stale records (e.g. via DNS cache poisoning) that persist after intended updates.

Impacts

  • Traffic Misrouting: Users continue to resolve to decommissioned or compromised endpoints.
  • Security Gaps: Old configurations (e.g. exposing test endpoints or weakly secured servers) remain reachable.
  • Operational Confusion: Inconsistent resolution leads to troubleshooting delays and lost revenue.
  • Compliance Risks: Inability to ensure correct record removal can breach data-governance policies.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Stale Entry Abuse: An administrator removes a dev.example.com test record but doesnt purge caches; attackers exploit the lingering DNS entry to access internal test servers.
  2. Cache Poisoning Persistence: After remediating a cache-poisoned A record, an attacker continues to intercept traffic because resolvers havent expired the poisoned entry.
  3. Automation Race Condition: A CI/CD job updates routing but skips validation; some regions still point at a deprecated service, causing intermittent failures for a subset of users.

weakness.name: CWE-1125
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1125: Excessive Attack Surface The product has an attack surface whose quantitative measurement exceeds a desirable maximum.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-250
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-250: Execution with Unnecessary Privileges The product performs an operation at a privilege level that is higher than the minimum level required, which creates new weaknesses or amplifies the consequences of other weaknesses.

weakness.name: CWE-276
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-276: Incorrect Default Permissions During installation, installed file permissions are set to allow anyone to modify those files.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-352
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-352: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) The web application does not, or can not, sufficiently verify whether a well-formed, valid, consistent request was intentionally provided by the user who submitted the request. When a web server is designed to receive a request from a client without any mechanism for verifying that it was intentionally sent, then it might be possible for an attacker to trick a client into making an unintentional request to the web server which will be treated as an authentic request. This can be done via a URL, image load, XMLHttpRequest, etc. and can result in exposure of data or unintended code execution.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

weakness.name: CWE-798
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-798: Use of Hard-coded Credentials The product contains hard-coded credentials, such as a password or cryptographic key, which it uses for its own inbound authentication, outbound communication to external components, or encryption of internal data.

countermeasure.name: Consider encryption of data at rest
countermeasure.desc:
You have the following options for protecting data at rest in Amazon S3:

  • Server-side encryption All Amazon S3 buckets have encryption configured by default, and all new objects that are uploaded to an S3 bucket are automatically encrypted at rest. Server-side encryption with Amazon S3 managed keys (SSE-S3) is the default encryption configuration for every bucket in Amazon S3. To use a different type of encryption, you can either specify the type of server-side encryption to use in your S3 PUT requests, or you can set the default encryption configuration in the destination bucket.

Amazon S3 also provides these server-side encryption options:

  • Server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (SSE-KMS)
  • Dual-layer server-side encryption with AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) keys (DSSE-KMS)
  • Server-side encryption with customer-provided keys (SSE-C)

For more information, see Protecting data with server-side encryption.

  • Client-side encryption Encrypt data client-side and upload the encrypted data to Amazon S3. In this case, you manage the encryption process, the encryption keys, and related tools. As with server-side encryption, client-side encryption can help reduce risk by encrypting the data with a key that is stored in a different mechanism than the mechanism that stores the data itself.

Amazon S3 provides multiple client-side encryption options. For more information, see Protecting data by using client-side encryption.

countermeasure.name: Consider using S3 Cross-Region Replication
countermeasure.desc:
Although Amazon S3 stores your data across multiple geographically diverse Availability Zones by default, compliance requirements might dictate that you store data at even greater distances. With S3 Cross-Region Replication (CRR), you can replicate data between distant AWS Regions to help satisfy these requirements. CRR enables automatic, asynchronous copying of objects across buckets in different AWS Regions. For more information, see Replicating objects.

Note

CRR requires both the source and destination S3 buckets to have versioning enabled.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-replication-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.desc:
With S3 Object Lock, you can store objects by using a "Write Once Read Many" (WORM) model. S3 Object Lock can help prevent accidental or inappropriate deletion of data. For example, you can use S3 Object Lock to help protect your AWS CloudTrail logs.

For more information, see Using S3 Object Lock.

countermeasure.name: Disable access control lists (ACLs) and use bucket policies to manage permissions
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Object Ownership is an Amazon S3 bucket-level setting that you can use to control ownership of objects uploaded to your bucket and to disable or enable ACLs. By default, Object Ownership is set to the Bucket owner enforced setting and all ACLs are disabled. When ACLs are disabled, the bucket owner owns all the objects in the bucket and manages access to data exclusively using access management policies.

A majority of modern use cases in Amazon S3 no longer require the use of access control lists (ACLs). We recommend that you disable ACLs, except in unusual circumstances where you must control access for each object individually. To disable ACLs and take ownership of every object in your bucket, apply the bucket owner enforced setting for S3 Object Ownership. When you disable ACLs, you can easily maintain a bucket with objects uploaded by different AWS accounts.

When ACLs are disabled access control for your data is based on policies, such as the following:

  • AWS Identity and Access Management (IAM) user policies
  • S3 bucket policies
  • Virtual private cloud (VPC) endpoint policies
  • AWS Organizations service control policies (SCPs)

Disabling ACLs simplifies permissions management and auditing. ACLs are disabled for new buckets by default. You can also disable ACLs for existing buckets. If you have an existing bucket that already has objects in it, after you disable ACLs, the object and bucket ACLs are no longer part of the access-evaluation process. Instead, access is granted or denied on the basis of policies.

Before you disable ACLs, make sure that you do the following:

  • Review your bucket policy to ensure that it covers all the ways that you intend to grant access to your bucket outside of your account.
  • Reset your bucket ACL to the default (full control to the bucket owner).

After you disable ACLs, the following behaviors occur:

  • Your bucket accepts only PUT requests that do not specify an ACL or PUT requests with bucket owner full control ACLs. These ACLs include the bucket-owner-full-control canned ACL or equivalent forms of this ACL that are expressed in XML.
  • Existing applications that support bucket owner full control ACLs see no impact.
  • PUT requests that contain other ACLs (for example, custom grants to certain AWS accounts) fail and return an HTTP status code 400 (Bad Request) with the error code AccessControlListNotSupported.

For more information, see Controlling ownership of objects and disabling ACLs for your bucket.

countermeasure.name: Discover sensitive data by using Amazon Macie
countermeasure.desc:
Amazon Macie is a security service that discovers sensitive data by using machine learning and pattern matching. Macie provides visibility into data security risks, and enables automated protection against those risks. With Macie, you can automate the discovery and reporting of sensitive data in your Amazon S3 data estate to gain a better understanding of the data that your organization stores in S3.

To detect sensitive data with Macie, you can use built-in criteria and techniques that are designed to detect a large and growing list of sensitive data types for many countries and regions. These sensitive data types include multiple types of personally identifiable information (PII), financial data, and credentials data. You can also use custom criteria that you defineregular expressions that define text patterns to match and, optionally, character sequences and proximity rules that refine the results.

If Macie detects sensitive data in an S3 object, Macie generates a security finding to notify you. This finding provides information about the affected object, the types and number of occurrences of the sensitive data that Macie found, and additional details to help you investigate the affected S3 bucket and object. For more information, see the Amazon Macie User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Enable Amazon S3 server access logging
countermeasure.desc:
Server access logging provides detailed records of the requests that are made to a bucket. Server access logs can assist you in security and access audits, help you learn about your customer base, and understand your Amazon S3 bill. For instructions on enabling server access logging, see Logging requests with server access logging.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-logging-enabled AWS Config managed rule.

countermeasure.name: Enable AWS Config
countermeasure.desc:
Several of the best practices listed in this topic suggest creating AWS Config rules. AWS Config helps you to assess, audit, and evaluate the configurations of your AWS resources. AWS Config monitors resource configurations so that you can evaluate the recorded configurations against the desired secure configurations. With AWS Config, you can do the following:

  • Review changes in configurations and relationships between AWS resources
  • Investigate detailed resource-configuration histories
  • Determine your overall compliance against the configurations specified in your internal guidelines

Using AWS Config can help you simplify compliance auditing, security analysis, change management, and operational troubleshooting. For more information, see Setting Up AWS Config with the Console in the AWS Config Developer Guide. When specifying the resource types to record, ensure that you include Amazon S3 resources.

Important

AWS Config managed rules only supports general purpose buckets when evaluating Amazon S3 resources. AWS Config doesnt record configuration changes for directory buckets. For more information, see AWS Config Managed Rules and List of AWS Config Managed Rules in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

For an example of how to use AWS Config, see How to Use AWS Config to Monitor for and Respond to Amazon S3 Buckets Allowing Public Access on the AWS Security Blog.

countermeasure.name: Enable S3 versioning
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Versioning is a means of keeping multiple variants of an object in the same bucket. You can use versioning to preserve, retrieve, and restore every version of every object stored in your bucket. With versioning, you can easily recover from both unintended user actions and application failures.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-versioning-enabled managed AWS Config rule.

For more information, see Using versioning in S3 buckets.

countermeasure.name: Enforce encryption of data in transit
countermeasure.desc:
You can use HTTPS (TLS) to help prevent potential attackers from eavesdropping on or manipulating network traffic by using person-in-the-middle or similar attacks. We recommend allowing only encrypted connections over HTTPS (TLS) by using the aws:SecureTransport condition in your Amazon S3 bucket policies.

Important

We recommend that your application not pin Amazon S3 TLS certificates as AWS doesnt support pinning of publicly-trusted certificates. S3 automatically renews certificates and renewal can happen any time before certificate expiry. Renewing a certificate generates a new public-private key pair. If youve pinned an S3 certificate which has been recently renewed with a new public key, you wont be able to connect to S3 until your application uses the new certificate.

Also consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-ssl-requests-only managed AWS Config rule.

countermeasure.name: Ensure that your Amazon S3 buckets use the correct policies and are not publicly accessible
countermeasure.desc:
Unless you explicitly require anyone on the internet to be able to read or write to your S3 bucket, make sure that your S3 bucket is not public. The following are some of the steps that you can take to block public access:

  • Use S3 Block Public Access. With S3 Block Public Access, you can easily set up centralized controls to limit public access to your Amazon S3 resources. These centralized controls are enforced regardless of how the resources are created. For more information, see Blocking public access to your Amazon S3 storage.
  • Identify Amazon S3 bucket policies that allow a wildcard identity such as "Principal": "*" (which effectively means "anyone"). Also look for policies that allow a wildcard action "*" (which effectively allows the user to perform any action in the Amazon S3 bucket).
  • Similarly, look for Amazon S3 bucket access control lists (ACLs) that provide read, write, or full-access to "Everyone" or "Any authenticated AWS user."
  • Use the ListBuckets API operation to scan all of your Amazon S3 buckets. Then use GetBucketAcl, GetBucketWebsite, and GetBucketPolicy to determine whether each bucket has compliant access controls and a compliant configuration.
  • Use AWS Trusted Advisor to inspect your Amazon S3 implementation.
  • Consider implementing ongoing detective controls by using the s3-bucket-public-read-prohibited and s3-bucket-public-write-prohibited managed AWS Config Rules.

For more information, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Identify and audit all of your Amazon S3 buckets
countermeasure.desc:
Identification of your IT assets is a crucial aspect of governance and security. You need to have visibility of all your Amazon S3 resources to assess their security posture and take action on potential areas of weakness. To audit your resources, we recommend doing the following:

  • Use Tag Editor to identify and tag security-sensitive or audit-sensitive resources, then use those tags when you need to search for these resources. For more information, see Searching for Resources to Tag in the Tagging AWS Resources User Guide.
  • Use S3 Inventory to audit and report on the replication and encryption status of your objects for business, compliance, and regulatory needs. For more information, see Amazon S3 Inventory.
  • Create resource groups for your Amazon S3 resources. For more information, see What are resource groups? in the AWS Resource Groups User Guide.

countermeasure.name: Identify potential threats to your Amazon S3 buckets by using Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Amazon GuardDuty is a threat detection service that identifies potential threats to your accounts, containers, workloads, and the data within your AWS environment. By using machine learning (ML) models, and anomaly and threat detection capabilities, Amazon GuardDuty continuously monitors different data sources to identify and prioritize potential security risks and malicious activities in your environment. When you enable GuardDuty, it offers threat detection for foundational data sources that includes AWS CloudTrail management events, VPC flow logs, and DNS logs. To extend threat detection to data plane events in S3 buckets, you can enable the GuardDuty S3 Protection feature. This feature detects threats such as data exfiltration and suspicious access to S3 buckets via Tor nodes. GuardDuty also establishes a normal baseline pattern in your environment and when it identifies a potentially anomalous behavior, it provides contextual information to help you remediate the potentially compromised S3 bucket or AWS credentials. For more information, see GuardDuty.

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege access
countermeasure.desc:
When granting permissions, you decide who is getting what permissions to which Amazon S3 resources. You enable specific actions that you want to allow on those resources. Therefore, we recommend that you grant only the permissions that are required to perform a task. Implementing least privilege access is fundamental in reducing security risk and the impact that could result from errors or malicious intent.

The following tools are available to implement least privilege access:

  • Policy actions for Amazon S3 and Permissions Boundaries for IAM Entities
  • How Amazon S3 works with IAM
  • Access control list (ACL) overview
  • Service Control Policies

For guidance on what to consider when choosing one or more of the preceding mechanisms, see Identity and Access Management for Amazon S3.

countermeasure.name: Implement monitoring by using AWS monitoring tools
countermeasure.desc:
Monitoring is an important part of maintaining the reliability, security, availability, and performance of Amazon S3 and your AWS solutions. AWS provides several tools and services to help you monitor Amazon S3 and your other AWS services. For example, you can monitor Amazon CloudWatch metrics for Amazon S3, particularly the PutRequests, GetRequests, 4xxErrors, and DeleteRequests metrics. For more information, see Monitoring metrics with Amazon CloudWatch and Monitoring Amazon S3.

For a second example, see Example: Amazon S3 Bucket Activity. This example describes how to create a CloudWatch alarm that is triggered when an Amazon S3 API call is made to PUT or DELETE a bucket policy, a bucket lifecycle, or a bucket replication configuration, or to PUT a bucket ACL.

countermeasure.name: Use AWS CloudTrail
countermeasure.desc:
AWS CloudTrail provides a record of actions taken by a user, a role, or an AWS service in Amazon S3. You can use information collected by CloudTrail to determine the following:

  • The request that was made to Amazon S3
  • The IP address from which the request was made
  • Who made the request
  • When the request was made
  • Additional details about the request

For example, you can identify CloudTrail entries for PUT actions that affect data access, in particular PutBucketAcl, PutObjectAcl, PutBucketPolicy, and PutBucketWebsite.

When you set up your AWS account, CloudTrail is enabled by default. You can view recent events in the CloudTrail console. To create an ongoing record of activity and events for your Amazon S3 buckets, you can create a trail in the CloudTrail console. For more information, see Logging data events in the AWS CloudTrail User Guide.

When you create a trail, you can configure CloudTrail to log data events. Data events are records of resource operations performed on or within a resource. In Amazon S3, data events record object-level API activity for individual buckets. CloudTrail supports a subset of Amazon S3 object-level API operations, such as GetObject, DeleteObject, and PutObject. For more information about how CloudTrail works with Amazon S3, see Logging Amazon S3 API calls using AWS CloudTrail. In the Amazon S3 console, you can also configure your S3 buckets to Enabling CloudTrail event logging for S3 buckets and objects.

AWS Config provides a managed rule (cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled) that you can use to confirm that at least one CloudTrail trail is logging data events for your S3 buckets. For more information, see cloudtrail-s3-dataevents-enabled in the AWS Config Developer Guide.

countermeasure.name: Use IAM roles for applications and AWS services that require Amazon S3 access
countermeasure.desc:
In order for applications running on Amazon EC2 or other AWS services to access Amazon S3 resources, they must include valid AWS credentials in their AWS API requests. We recommend not storing AWS credentials directly in the application or Amazon EC2 instance. These are long-term credentials that are not automatically rotated and could have a significant business impact if they are compromised.

Instead, use an IAM role to manage temporary credentials for applications or services that need to access Amazon S3. When you use a role, you don't have to distribute long-term credentials (such as a username and password or access keys) to an Amazon EC2 instance or AWS service, such as AWS Lambda. The role supplies temporary permissions that applications can use when they make calls to other AWS resources.

For more information, see the following topics in the IAM User Guide:

  • IAM Roles
  • Common Scenarios for Roles: Users, Applications, and Services

countermeasure.name: Use S3 Storage Lens
countermeasure.desc:
S3 Storage Lens is a cloud-storage analytics feature that you can use to gain organization-wide visibility into object-storage usage and activity. S3 Storage Lens also analyzes metrics to deliver contextual recommendations that you can use to optimize storage costs and apply best practices for protecting your data.

With S3 Storage Lens, you can use metrics to generate summary insights, such as finding out how much storage you have across your entire organization or which are the fastest-growing buckets and prefixes. You can also use S3 Storage Lens metrics to identify cost-optimization opportunities, implement data-protection and access-management best practices, and improve the performance of application workloads.

For example, you can identify buckets that don't have S3 Lifecycle rules to abort incomplete multipart uploads that are more than 7 days old. You can also identify buckets that aren't following data-protection best practices, such as using S3 Replication or S3 Versioning. For more information, see Understanding Amazon S3 Storage Lens.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized extraction of sensitive data from S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Sensitive data stored in Amazon S3 buckets may be extracted without proper oversight due to inadequate monitoring and insufficient access controls. This can lead to unauthorized data access, leaks, and breaches, compromising the integrity and confidentiality of the data.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include malicious insiders, external attackers, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak access controls, lack of encryption, and insufficient logging and monitoring mechanisms, allowing undetected data exfiltration.

Impacts

Impacts include severe data breaches, loss of intellectual property, financial losses, legal consequences due to non-compliance with data protection regulations, and damage to an organization's reputation and customer trust.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An insider with access to an S3 bucket containing sensitive customer information downloads the data without being detected due to a lack of proper monitoring and oversight.
  2. An external attacker compromises an employee's AWS credentials and uses them to extract sensitive data from an S3 bucket, leading to a significant data breach and regulatory fines.
  3. Sensitive financial data stored in an S3 bucket is exfiltrated by an attacker exploiting overly permissive access controls, resulting in the exposure of confidential business information and competitive disadvantage.
  4. A lack of proper logging and alerting mechanisms allows an attacker to continuously extract small amounts of sensitive data over an extended period, going unnoticed until the breach is discovered during an audit.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1011 - Exfiltration Over Other Network Medium

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Inadequate monitoring of S3 buckets
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

The lack of adequate monitoring of Amazon S3 buckets can result in undetected data breaches or data loss. Without proper logging, alerting, and monitoring mechanisms, unauthorized access or malicious activities can go unnoticed, leading to severe security and compliance issues.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and compromised accounts. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or non-existent monitoring systems, allowing attackers to access, modify, or extract data without detection.

Impacts

Impacts include significant data breaches, loss of sensitive and critical data, non-compliance with regulatory requirements, financial losses, and damage to the organization's reputation and customer trust. The inability to detect and respond to security incidents in a timely manner exacerbates these risks.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An attacker gains unauthorized access to an S3 bucket and exfiltrates sensitive data over time. Due to inadequate monitoring, the breach remains undetected until the data is leaked or sold on the dark web, resulting in a major security incident.
  2. An insider with malicious intent deletes critical business data from an S3 bucket. Without proper monitoring and alerting mechanisms, the data loss is not identified until business operations are disrupted, causing significant financial and operational impacts.
  3. During a routine compliance audit, an organization discovers that an S3 bucket containing regulated data has been accessed by unauthorized users multiple times over the past year, leading to substantial fines and legal consequences.
  4. A lack of detailed logging and alerting allows an attacker to use compromised credentials to make unauthorized changes to an S3 bucket policy, granting themselves ongoing access and leading to a prolonged data breach that goes unnoticed for months.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Insecure S3 bucket configurations
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Amazon S3 buckets that are not properly secured may be accessible by unauthorized users. This can result from misconfigured permissions, lack of encryption, and absence of stringent access controls, leading to potential data breaches and unauthorized data access.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

Threat agents include external attackers, malicious insiders, and automated bots scanning for misconfigured buckets. Attack vectors involve exploiting weak or incorrect bucket policies, overly permissive access controls, and publicly accessible buckets without proper security measures.

Impacts

Impacts include unauthorized access to sensitive data, data breaches, loss of intellectual property, compliance violations, financial penalties, and damage to the organization's reputation. Misconfigured buckets can also lead to data manipulation or deletion, further compromising data integrity and availability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. An S3 bucket containing confidential customer data is mistakenly configured with public read access, allowing anyone on the internet to access and download sensitive information, resulting in a significant data breach.
  2. During a routine security scan, it is discovered that several S3 buckets are accessible to unauthorized internal users due to misconfigured IAM policies, leading to unauthorized access and potential data leaks.
  3. An external attacker uses automated tools to identify and access an S3 bucket that has been inadvertently left publicly accessible. The attacker exfiltrates proprietary business information, causing financial and reputational damage to the company.
  4. A developer unintentionally grants write permissions to all authenticated AWS users on an S3 bucket, allowing unauthorized users to upload malicious content or delete critical data, leading to operational disruptions and potential legal issues.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1526 - Cloud Service Discovery

weakness.name: CWE-1298
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1298: Hardware Logic Contains Race Conditions A race condition in the hardware logic results in undermining security guarantees of the system.

weakness.name: CWE-272
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-272: Least Privilege Violation The elevated privilege level required to perform operations such as chroot() should be dropped immediately after the operation is performed.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-626
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-626: Null Byte Interaction Error (Poison Null Byte) The product does not properly handle null bytes or NUL characters when passing data between different representations or components.

weakness.name: CWE-668
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-668: Exposure of Resource to Wrong Sphere The product exposes a resource to the wrong control sphere, providing unintended actors with inappropriate access to the resource.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Conduct regular security audits and configuration reviews of endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
Institute a recurring security-audit cycle (e.g., monthly in non-prod, quarterly in prod) that inspects every interface and gateway VPC endpoint for drift, over-permissive policies, and network exposure.

  1. Baseline once, then automate
    • Export an inventory with aws ec2 describe-vpc-endpoints and record the service name, subnets, security-group IDs, private-DNS status, and any endpoint policy attached.
    • Store the CSV or JSON in your compliance bucket for change tracking.
  2. Enable continuous controls
    • Turn on AWS Config and activate managed rules such as VPC_ENDPOINT_PUBLIC_ACCESS_CHECK (custom) and vpc-sg-open-only-to-authorized-ports; send non-compliant findings to Security Hub.
    • Use IAM Access Analyzer on each account to detect cross-account endpoint policies that grant unintended access.
  3. Run targeted checks in CI/CD
    • Add a pipeline step that lints CloudFormation/Terraform templatesfail if an endpoint SG allows 0.0.0.0/0, if the endpoint is in fewer than two AZ-spanning subnets, or if its policy lacks aws:SourceAccount/aws:SourceVpce conditions.
  4. Review flow logs and metrics
    • Enable VPC Flow Logs on endpoint ENIs; set CloudWatch alarms on rejected connections or traffic from unexpected CIDRs.
    • For gateway endpoints (S3/DynamoDB), query Athena to spot anomalous source IPs or sudden spikes in request volume.
  5. Produce and track an audit report
    • After each cycle, publish a short report listing compliant, drifted, and remediated endpoints.
    • Use a ticketing system to assign fixes and verify closure before the next audit window.
  6. Evolve the checklist
    • Update rules when new endpoint service names, AZs, or security guidance appears.
    • Retire unused endpoints to cut costs and shrink the attack surface.

Regular, tool-backed audits catch misconfigurations early, keep endpoint posture aligned with least-privilege principles, and provide evidence for compliance frameworks like ISO 27001 or SOC 2.

References

  • Monitoring and troubleshooting interface VPC endpoints
  • AWS Config rules for VPC security

countermeasure.name: Define a clear regional deployment strategy for endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
Plan and document where each interface or gateway VPC endpoint will live so traffic always stays in-Region, latency is predictable, and fail-over is routinenot improvised.

  • Map service needs by Region list every AWS service your workload calls (S3, KMS, STS, Lambda, ECR, etc.) and note the Regions in which the workload actually runs. Deploy endpoints only in those Regions; do not rely on cross-Region NAT or public endpoints, which add latency and may break compliance.
  • Replicate critical endpoints for multi-Region active/active or DR architectures, create the same endpoint set in the secondary Regions VPC so the application can flip over without adding new routes or security-group rules mid-incident.
  • Isolate per-Region traffic use Region-specific DNS (enabled by Private DNS) and route tables that keep service calls local; never route *.amazonaws.com traffic back over VPN or TGW to another Region.
  • Automate in IaC modules build one Terraform/CloudFormation module per Region, parameterised with subnet IDs and security groups. Tag every endpoint with Environment, Region, and Owner so Ops can audit deployments quickly.
  • Review and update quarterly when workloads move or a new service becomes available in a Region, add the endpoint to the regional module; remove endpoints from Regions you no longer operate in to reduce cost and attack surface.

A clear, codified regional strategy prevents surprise egress to the public internet, reduces blast radius during a regional event, and keeps endpoint governance simple and repeatable.

References

  • Interface VPC endpoints are Region-specific AWS PrivateLink docs

countermeasure.name: Develop an incident response plan for potential endpoint compromise
countermeasure.desc:
Create a documented playbookkept in version control and tested at least twice a yearthat walks responders through every phase of a suspected VPC interface or gateway endpoint breach:

  1. Preparation
    • Define roles (incident commander, network lead, comms lead).
    • Pre-provision IAM break-glass roles with least-privilege ability to modify/disable endpoints and view logs.
    • Enable CloudTrail, VPC Flow Logs, and GuardDuty findings export to an immutable S3 bucket for rapid forensic access.
  2. Detection & triage
    • Trigger on GuardDuty findings (e.g., PrivilegedIPAddress, UnauthorizedAccess:IAMUser/NetworkPermissions) or Config violations that flag over-permissive endpoint policies.
    • Use CloudWatch alarms on unusual traffic spikes or rejected flows to the endpoint ENIs.
  3. Containment
    • Immediately attach a quarantine security group that denies all inbound traffic except from the IR subnet.
    • If cross-account exposure is suspected, replace the endpoint policy with a deny-all policy while analysis continues.
    • Update route tables or NACLs to route affected service traffic through a known-good secondary endpoint.
  4. Eradication & recovery
    • Reimage or patch compromised instances.
    • Rotate any IAM roles or KMS keys referenced by the endpoint policy.
    • Replace the compromised endpoint with a freshly created one in the same subnets; redeploy the validated policy and SG rules.
  5. Post-incident analysis
    • Perform root-cause analysis, capture timeline and blast radius.
    • Update the playbook, Config rules, and CI lint rules that failed to prevent the issue.
    • Conduct a game-day exercise to validate that the new controls detect and contain the simulated breach.
  6. Documentation & training
    • Store the plan alongside runbooks in a version-controlled repo; require sign-off from SecOps and platform teams after any major architecture change.
    • Deliver quarterly tabletop sessions so responders stay familiar with the tools and escalation paths.

A rehearsed, service-specific incident-response plan ensures you can isolate a compromised VPC endpoint within minutes, preserve forensic data, and restore secure connectivity with minimal downtime.

References

  • AWS Well-Architected Incident response best practices

countermeasure.name: Enable comprehensive logging and monitoring
countermeasure.desc:
Collect and analyze every data point that can reveal misuse or drift of your interface and gateway VPC endpoints:

  1. CloudTrail for control-plane activity
    • Ensure an organization-wide, multi-Region trail is logging Management events so you see every CreateVpcEndpoint, ModifyVpcEndpoint, or policy change.
    • Deliver the trail to an SSE-KMSencrypted S3 bucket and stream it to CloudWatch Logs or Security Lake for near-real-time alerting.
  2. VPC Flow Logs for data-plane visibility
    • Enable Flow Logs on the subnets that host the endpoint ENIs and on the endpoint network interfaces themselves; set the log format to include flow-direction, pkt-src-aws-service, and pkt-dst-aws-service.
    • Send logs to CloudWatch Logs with a retention policy 90 days or to S3 + Athena for deeper queries.
  3. GuardDuty & Network Firewall
    • Turn on Amazon GuardDuty to detect anomalous traffic, port scans, or credential exfiltration that targets the endpoint.
    • If you use AWS Network Firewall or third-party IDS, mirror endpoint traffic through Gateway Load Balancer endpoints for deep packet inspection.
  4. CloudWatch metrics & alarms
    • Create CloudWatch metrics filters (or use Contributor Insights) that count rejected Flow Log entries or sudden spikes in bytes transferred.
    • Alarm on:
      • 0 rejects from unexpected CIDRs,
      • traffic volume 2 the 30-day average,
      • CloudTrail events such as DeleteVpcEndpoint.
  5. Automated findings & response
    • Use AWS Config rules (VPC_ENDPOINT_PUBLIC_ACCESS_CHECK, custom SG/NACL checks) to flag over-permissive changes.
    • Pipe Config and GuardDuty findings to Security Hub; auto-remediate with EventBridge Lambda if the endpoint policy or SG becomes open to 0.0.0.0/0.
  6. Review & retention
    • Store logs for at least one year (or your compliance window) in Glacier Instant Retrieval / Deep Archive.
    • Run quarterly log reviewsvalidate that alerts fired, tune thresholds, and confirm no blind spots remain.

Comprehensive, layered logging lets you detect misuse quickly, perform root-cause analysis, and prove compliance for data-in-transit controls around your private endpoints.

References

  • Monitoring and troubleshooting interface VPC endpoints
  • VPC Flow Logs capture information about the IP traffic going to and from network interfaces

countermeasure.name: Enforce instance and resource security for workloads using endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
A private VPC endpoint is useful only if the EC2 instances, containers, or Lambda functions that call it are equally well-protected. Apply defense-in-depth controls to every workload that relies on an endpoint:

  • Lock down network paths attach a least-privilege security group to each instance or pod: allow outbound TCP 443 (or the service port) only to the endpoints subnet CIDRs or security group, and remove the default all traffic egress rule.
  • Use IAM roles, not keys grant the workload an IAM role scoped to the minimal *:* actions it needs; deny wildcard resources.
  • Require encrypted traffic enforce aws:SecureTransport in resource policies, use TLS 1.2+ in client libraries, and store data on SSE-KMS encrypted EBS volumes or EFS with encryption at rest.
  • Harden the OS / runtime enable IMDSv2, patch the AMI through AWS Systems Manager Patch Manager, disable unused services, and run Inspector or another CIS benchmark scanner weekly.
  • Monitor continuously stream instance VPC Flow Logs, GuardDuty findings, and CloudWatch metrics to a central dashboard; alarm on traffic that bypasses the endpoint or on policy-denied calls.
  • Automate drift detection use AWS Config rules (required-tags, custom SG/NACL checks) and a CI lint step that fails if a workload security group opens 0.0.0.0/0 or if IMDSv2 is disabled.

By securing the calling resources as tightly as the endpoint itself, you prevent lateral movement, limit the blast radius of a compromise, and keep data flows private and compliant.

References

  • AWS Well-Architected Security Pillar Protecting compute resources
  • Best practices for securing traffic through VPC endpoints

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

countermeasure.name: Implement data exfiltration prevention measures
countermeasure.desc:
Deploy layered controls that make it impossible for traffic to leave your VPC through an interface or gateway endpoint unless it matches an approved destination and payload:

  1. Denybydefault endpoint policies
    • Start every endpoint policy with Effect: Deny to Principal:"*" and Action:"*" on Resource:"*".
    • Add least-privilege Allow statements for the exact API calls, resource ARNs, and accounts you trust.
    • For S3 gateway endpoints, pair the policy with bucket policies that contain aws:SourceVpce and aws:SourceAccount conditions so data cant be copied to unapproved buckets or Regions.
  2. Tight security groups & NACLs
    • Attach an endpoint SG that allows only TCP 443 from the application SGs; block all egress except return traffic.
    • In the workload SG, permit outbound traffic only to the endpoint ENI SG or its private CIDRs. Remove the default allow-all egress rule.
  3. DNS & route-table controls
    • Enable Private DNS so the SDK always resolves service names to the endpoint.
    • Add a DNS Firewall rule or Route 53 Resolver rule that blocks direct hits on public service hostnames (s3.amazonaws.com, etc.), forcing workloads to use the endpoint path.
  4. Traffic inspection & alerting
    • Stream VPC Flow Logs for endpoint ENIs to CloudWatch Logs or S3 + Athena; set metric filters that fire if traffic exceeds normal baselines or if the dest-port/CIDR isnt 443 AWS.
    • Enable GuardDuty and turn on the Data Exfiltration via VPC Endpoint finding type.
    • Deploy AWS Network Firewall / Gateway Load Balancer in front of outbound routes; write stateless rules that drop packets whose TLS SNI or HTTP Host doesnt match the approved AWS service domains.
  5. Automated drift detection
    • Use AWS Config custom rules that mark an endpoint NON_COMPLIANT if its policy allows *, if its SG opens to 0.0.0.0/0, or if the subnet route table has an Internet Gateway path.
    • Fail CI/CD builds when a template tries to add an Allow statement without a matching aws:SourceVpce or aws:SourceAccount condition.
  6. Periodic validation
    • Quarterly, run Reachability Analyzer tests and Red Team scenarios to prove data cant exit via the endpoint.
    • Review GuardDuty / Network Firewall findings and tweak flow-log alarms to keep false positives low and coverage high.

Implementing these controls stops attackers or misconfigured applications from tunnelling data through your private endpoints, while still letting legitimate, in-region service calls succeed.

References

  • Best practices for securing VPC endpoints
  • Amazon GuardDuty data exfiltration detections

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1031 - Network Intrusion Prevention

countermeasure.name: Implement least privilege using endpoint policies and IAM roles
countermeasure.desc:
Tie down every interface or gateway VPC endpoint with a deny-by-default endpoint policy and allow access only through IAM roles that carry the minimum actions and resources required:

  • Start with a blanket deny. In the endpoint policy, add {"Effect":"Deny","Principal":"*","Action":"*","Resource":"*"} first.
  • List explicit allows. Add specific statements that permit only the API actions (for example s3:PutObject, kms:Decrypt) and ARNs the workload needs, and include aws:SourceAccount + aws:SourceVpce or aws:SourceVpc conditions to prevent confused-deputy and cross-VPC abuse.
  • Use purpose-built IAM roles.
    • Give each application or Lambda function its own role.
    • Scope policies to the exact service, resource, and prefix; never use wildcards (*) unless you truly own every resource in scope.
    • Attach the roles ARNnot an access keyto the compute resource so it receives short-lived STS credentials.
  • Layer the controls. The request must pass both the IAM policy attached to the role and the endpoint policy; if either denies, the call fails. This dual evaluation sharply narrows blast radius.
  • Automate validation.
    • Add CI/CD lint checks (cfn-nag, Checkov, Guard) that fail if an endpoint policy includes "Principal":"*" without restrictive conditions or if an IAM policy grants Action:"*" or Resource:"*".
    • Enable AWS Config rules or Security Hub controls to flag public or overly broad endpoint policies.
  • Review quarterly. Use IAM Access Analyzer to surface unused permissions, then prune the Allow list; update the endpoint policy whenever new resources are added so you never revert to wildcards.

Applying least privilege at both the network boundary (endpoint policy) and identity boundary (IAM role) ensures that even if one layer is mis-configured, the other still blocks unauthorized calls, keeping data flows tightly controlled.

References

  • Controlling access to VPC endpoints with endpoint policies
  • IAM policies and evaluation logic

standard.ref: PR.AC-4: Access permissions and authorizations are managed, incorporating the principles of least privilege and separation of duties
PR.PT-3: The principle of least functionality is incorporated by configuring systems to provide only essential capabilities

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1036 - Account Use Policies

countermeasure.name: Restrict VPC endpoint traffic with SGs, NACLs, and route-table rules
countermeasure.desc:
Lock down every interface or gateway VPC endpoint so it can be reached only by the workloads that truly need it:

  1. Security groups (first line of defense)
    • Attach a dedicated endpoint SG that allows inbound TCP 443 (or the services port) only from the CIDR blocks / SGs of your producer subnets or application tiers.
    • Remove the default all-traffic egress rule; add specific egress ports only if the endpoint must initiate connections (rare).
  2. Network ACLs (subnet perimeter)
    • Apply a subnet-level NACL that allows ingress 443 and related ephemeral ports from your trusted CIDRs and denies everything else.
    • Mirror the rule set for egress; deny outbound traffic to unintended networks (e.g., 0.0.0.0/0) unless routing requires it.
  3. Route-table hygiene
    • Ensure the private-subnet route table sends service traffic to the endpoint ENI (pl-xxxx or vpce-xxxx) and not to the Internet/NAT Gateway.
    • Keep route tables in other subnets free of stray prefixes that could steer traffic around the endpoint.
  4. Verification & monitoring
    • Enable VPC Flow Logs on the endpoint ENIs; alert on rejected connections or unexpected source IPs.
    • Run Reachability Analyzer or AWS Network Firewall Insights after each change to confirm only intended paths succeed.
  5. Automation
    • Encapsulate SG, NACL, and route-table rules in IaC modules; add CI linting that fails if an endpoint SG exposes 0.0.0.0/0 or a NACL rule is overly broad.
    • Use AWS Config managed rules (vpc-sg-open-only-to-authorized-ports, custom NACL checks) to flag drift and auto-remediate.

Strict, layered controls ensure the endpoint cannot be abused as an unintended ingress or egress path, keeping service calls private and compliant.

References

  • Controlling access to interface VPC endpoints with security groups
  • VPC network ACLs and flow of traffic

countermeasure.name: Utilize secure private DNS configuration and resolution for interface endpoints
countermeasure.desc:
For every interface VPC endpoint (AWS PrivateLink), turn on Private DNS so the standard AWS service hostname (e.g., s3.<region>.amazonaws.com) automatically resolves to the endpoints in-VPC IP addresses, and prevent resolvers from falling back to the public address space.

  1. Enable Private DNS at creation
    • Console: Create interface endpoint DNS options Enable private DNS name.
    • CLI / IaC: omit --private-dns-enabled false, or set PrivateDnsEnabled: true in CloudFormation/Terraform.
  2. Harden resolver paths
    • Add a Route 53 Resolver outbound rule (or DNS Firewall rule) that blocks public lookups for the same domain, forcing workloads to use the private mapping.
    • If on-prem or another VPC must resolve the name, create a Resolver inbound endpoint and a forwarding rule that hands the domain to the VPCs private DNS.
  3. Verify resolution
    • From a host in the VPC run dig +short s3.<region>.amazonaws.com it should return a 10.x/172.x address, not a public IP.
    • Disable the Internet/NAT gateway briefly and confirm service calls still succeed.
  4. Monitor drift
    • Enable AWS Config (or a custom rule) to flag endpoints where PrivateDnsEnabled = false.
    • Turn on VPC Flow Logs for the endpoint ENIs and alarm if traffic is sent to the public AWS service IP range (52.216.0.0/15, etc.).
  5. Document & review
    • Keep a runbook listing all private DNS zones and forwarding rules; review quarterly as new services or Regions are added.

Private DNS guarantees that traffic to AWS services stays on the AWS backbone, blocks spoofing, and simplifies firewall rules by using the same familiar hostnames everywhere.

References

  • Interface VPC endpoints and private DNS names
  • Route 53 Resolver rules for on-premises and cross-VPC DNS forwarding
