customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1037 - Filter Network Traffic

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Excessive permissions in endpoint policy
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
An overly permissive VPC Endpoint policy grants principals more access than intendedoften using wildcards for Principal, Action, or Resourceallowing unauthorized actors or networks to use the endpoint to reach AWS services.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised IAM credentials, unauthorized third-party accounts
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Principal: "*" or broad IAM ARNs in the endpoint policy
    • Missing conditions such as aws:sourceVpce or aws:sourceIp
    • Wildcard actions (e.g. s3:*) or resources (arn:aws:s3:::*) in the policy

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Service Access: Attackers can read or write data via the endpoint (e.g., S3, DynamoDB)
  • Data Exfiltration & Tampering: Misuse of the endpoint to steal or corrupt sensitive data
  • Network Bypass: Unintended networks or accounts bypass NAT/firewall controls via the private link
  • Compliance Risks: Violations of least-privilege and network-segmentation mandates

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Open S3 Access: An endpoint policy allows any principal to call s3:* on all bucketsan attacker uses it to list and download confidential objects.
  2. Cross-Account DynamoDB Reads: Missing sourceVpce condition lets a third-party account query your DynamoDB tables via the shared endpoint.
  3. IP-Unrestricted Secrets Manager: A wildcard resource policy on the Secrets Manager endpoint lets any VPC host retrieve database credentials, bypassing intended network restrictions.

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Data exfiltration through a broadly configured VPC endpoint
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A broadly configured VPC endpointone that allows wide principals, actions, or source networkscan be misused to funnel sensitive data out of your VPC to external or unauthorized recipients.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised instances, and unauthorized third-party accounts
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Endpoint policies with Principal: "*" or missing aws:sourceVpce/sourceIp conditions
    • Overly permissive actions (e.g. s3:GetObject on all buckets)
    • Rogue code on EC2/Lambda using the endpoint to pull and forward data externally

Impacts

  • Unauthorized extraction of confidential data (PII, intellectual property)
  • Bypassing of network egress controls and NAT/firewall restrictions
  • Compliance violations and regulatory penalties

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. S3 Data Leak: A compromised EC2 in the VPC uses a wildcard-permitted S3 endpoint to download sensitive objects and uploads them to an external server.
  2. Secrets Extraction: A Lambda with access to the Secrets Manager endpoint pulls all secrets and sends them over HTTPS to an attackers domain.
  3. Cross-Account Exfiltration: An external AWS account assumed a role is allowed by the endpoint policy; it reads your DynamoDB table via the endpoint and exfiltrates the data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1537 - Transfer Data to Cloud Account

threat.name: Unintended cross-region data flows via improperly placed endpoints
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
Improper placement of VPC Endpoints across AWS regions can inadvertently route trafficand thus sensitive datathrough unintended geographic locations, causing cross-region data flows that violate data residency, latency, or compliance requirements.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Misguided administrators, automated deployment scripts, and malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Creating or replicating interface endpoints in the wrong region or account
    • DNS configurations that resolve service names to regional endpoints outside of the intended region
    • Infrastructure-as-code templates that omit region-specific constraints

Impacts

  • Compliance Violations: Data processed or stored in unauthorized jurisdictions breaches regulations (GDPR, HIPAA, etc.)
  • Increased Latency & Costs: Traffic detours across regions incur higher network charges and slower response times
  • Data Exposure Risks: Cross-region transfers expand the attack surface and may bypass localized security controls

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Template Misdeploy: A CloudFormation module deploys an S3 VPC Endpoint in us-west-2 instead of us-east-1; application traffic carrying PII traverses to that region, violating data-sovereignty rules.
  2. DNS Override Error: A global DNS record for the Secrets Manager endpoint resolves to a Europe-based VPCE, causing US-only services to fetch secrets through an EU endpoint and exposing them to EU-based monitoring.
  3. Automation Drift: CI/CD pipelines automatically instantiate interface endpoints in every region; a dev team inadvertently routes production database backups through an unintended region, incurring extra egress fees and broader exposure.

threat.name: DNS manipulation redirecting traffic intended for an interface endpoint
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
DNS manipulation attacks forged or poisoned DNS responses so that traffic meant for an AWS Interface VPC Endpoint (via its private DNS name) is redirected to attacker-controlled IPs. This subverts AWS PrivateLink security by hijacking service traffic.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised resolvers, or on-premise network attackers
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Poisoning local DNS caches or DHCP-supplied DNS settings to return attacker IPs for the endpoints private DNS name
    • Compromising on-prem DNS servers used in hybrid architectures
    • Exploiting host-level /etc/hosts or resolver overrides on EC2 instances

Impacts

  • Data Interception: Sensitive API traffic (e.g., to S3, KMS, Secrets Manager) is sent to rogue endpoints for eavesdropping.
  • Credential Theft: Stolen tokens or credentials in transit enable further compromise.
  • Service Disruption: Legitimate service calls fail or are silently dropped.
  • Regulatory & Compliance Risks: Breach of data-in-transit protections undermines compliance with standards like PCI DSS or HIPAA.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. On-Prem Resolver Poisoning: An attacker plants a false A record in the corporate DNS for secretsmanager.us-east-1.vpce.amazonaws.com, pointing to their server. All on-prem clients push secret-management traffic to the attacker.
  2. EC2 Hosts File Tamper: A malicious process modifies /etc/hosts on EC2 instances so the interface endpoint DNS name resolves to an external IP, diverting traffic and capturing S3 object data.
  3. Hybrid DHCP Hijack: Through rogue DHCP in a branch office, the attacker supplies controlled DNS servers that resolve interface endpoints to attacker nodes, allowing MITM of all PrivateLink calls.

threat.name: Lack of visibility into endpoint usage and potential misuse
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When VPC Endpoint activity isnt logged or monitoredvia VPC Flow Logs, CloudTrail, or GuardDutyusage patterns and malicious behavior (data exfiltration, unauthorized access) can occur without detection, leaving your private link infrastructure blind to threats.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malicious insiders, compromised EC2/Lambda roles, external attackers with network access
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Calling endpoint APIs or services through the endpoint without generating or reviewing logs
    • Abusing overly permissive policies to pass unauthorized traffic
    • Leveraging undetected endpoint tunnels for data exfiltration or command-and-control

Impacts

  • Undetected Misuse: Sensitive data transfers or unauthorized service calls go unnoticed
  • Delayed Incident Response: Lack of alerts on anomalous endpoint patterns prolongs breach dwell time
  • Compliance Gaps: Failure to audit endpoint usage violates regulations requiring network monitoring
  • Increased Blast Radius: Unmonitored tunnels facilitate lateral movement within your VPC

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Stealthy Data Exfiltration: An attacker uses a compromised EC2 role to pull S3 objects via the endpoint; without Flow Logs or CloudTrail entries, the exfiltration isnt detected.
  2. Unauthorized Service Calls: A rogue Lambda function invokes Secrets Manager through a VPC Endpoint; absent GuardDuty alerts on anomalous API calls, the secret retrieval goes unnoticed.
  3. Covert C2 Channel: Malware sets up a DNS-over-HTTPS tunnel through the endpoint to a benign AWS service; without monitoring of endpoint traffic patterns, the command-and-control channel persists undetected.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1027 - Obfuscated Files or Information

threat.name: Misconfigured security group exposing endpoint ENI to unintended sources
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
When the security group attached to a VPC Endpoints Elastic Network Interface (ENI) is too permissive or mis-scoped, unintended sourcessuch as the public Internet or off-limits subnetscan reach the endpoint, undermining PrivateLinks isolation guarantees.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: External attackers, compromised EC2 instances, malicious insiders
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Security group rules allowing 0.0.0.0/0 or overly broad CIDRs on the ENIs ports (e.g., TCP 443)
    • Inadvertently reusing a public-facing security group for the endpoint
    • Failure to restrict ingress to the VPCs trusted subnets or specific source VPC Endpoint IDs

Impacts

  • Unauthorized Access: Unapproved systems or Internet hosts can call the endpoint and reach the backend service
  • Data Exposure & Tampering: Sensitive API calls or data can be intercepted or manipulated
  • Bypass of Network Controls: Firewall, NAT, or proxy protections are circumvented, expanding the attackers lateral movement options
  • Compliance Breaches: Violation of network-segmentation and data-protection requirements

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Public Internet Reachability: A security group with 0.0.0.0/0 on HTTPS is applied to the endpoint ENI. An external scanner discovers the endpoint and issues requests to S3 via PrivateLink, harvesting confidential objects.
  2. Cross-Subnet Abuse: A QA security group is mistakenly attached to the production endpoint. Hosts in an unrestricted dev subnet exploit it to access production Secrets Manager secrets.
  3. Insider Misconfiguration: A malicious administrator reuses a broad web-tier SG for a new endpoint. An unauthorized application in a different VPC uses the open ingress to invoke internal APIs and exfiltrate data.

usecase.name: Lateral Movement
usecase.desc: Lateral Movement refers to the technique used by attackers to move horizontally across a network after gaining initial access. Once inside a network, attackers seek to explore and compromise additional systems to escalate their attack and access valuable resources.

threat.name: Compromised instance within the VPC abusing an endpoint
threat.desc:
General Threat Description
A compromised EC2 instance or container within your VPC can leverage a VPC Endpoints private connectivity to abuse downstream AWS servicesbypassing Internet gateways and security controlsto exfiltrate data, invoke privileged APIs, or move laterally.

Threat Agents / Attack Vectors

  • Threat Agents: Malware-infected or attacker-controlled EC2 instances, compromised ECS/EKS workloads.
  • Attack Vectors:
    • Using the endpoints DNS name and IAM role to call services (e.g. S3, Secrets Manager) directly over the private link.
    • Scripted exploitation of overly broad endpoint policies from the compromised host.
    • Automated tools on the instance scanning and abusing any available endpoints in its VPC.

Impacts

  • Data Exfiltration: Stolen objects or secrets are pulled via the endpoint and forwarded externally.
  • Privilege Escalation: The instance invokes sensitive APIs (e.g. IAM, KMS) to expand access.
  • Lateral Movement: Compromise spreads to other services or accounts accessible through the endpoint.
  • Audit Blindness: Private-link activity may bypass perimeter monitoring, delaying detection.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Secrets Harvest: An attackers backdoor on an EC2 uses the VPC Endpoint for Secrets Manager to retrieve database credentials, then uploads them to an external server.
  2. S3 Data Leak: A compromised container scripts aws s3 sync over the S3 VPC Endpoint, mirroring sensitive data to attacker-controlled storage.
  3. IAM Role Abuse: Malware on an instance exploits its attached role via the endpoint to call sts:AssumeRole on a higher-privilege cross-account role, pivoting across your AWS environment.

weakness.name: CWE-200
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-200: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product exposes sensitive information to an actor that is not explicitly authorized to have access to that information.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-778
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-778: Insufficient Logging When a security-critical event occurs, the product either does not record the event or omits important details about the event when logging it.

countermeasure.name: Control traffic using network ACLs
countermeasure.desc: Manage inbound and outbound traffic at the subnet level by configuring network Access Control Lists (ACLs) in your VPC. Network ACLs act as stateless firewalls for your subnets, allowing you to set rules that permit or deny traffic based on IP protocol, port number, and source/destination IP address. To implement this, navigate to the VPC section in the AWS Management Console, create or modify network ACLs, and associate them with the appropriate subnets. Regularly review and update ACL rules to enhance security and compliance.

countermeasure.name: Detect potential threats with Amazon GuardDuty
countermeasure.desc: Enable Amazon GuardDuty to continuously monitor VPC flow logs for malicious activity and potential security threats. GuardDuty uses machine learning and threat intelligence to analyze traffic patterns and detect anomalies. To implement this, activate GuardDuty in the AWS Management Console, configure it to ingest VPC flow logs, DNS logs, and CloudTrail event logs. Regularly review GuardDuty findings and take appropriate actions to mitigate identified threats, ensuring your VPC remains secure against evolving attack vectors.

countermeasure.name: Distribute subnets across multiple availability zones
countermeasure.desc: To ensure high availability, fault tolerance, and scalability of your applications hosted on Amazon VPC, create subnets in multiple Availability Zones (AZs) within the same AWS Region. An Availability Zone comprises one or more data centers with independent power, networking, and connectivity. By distributing subnets across multiple AZs, you can mitigate the risk of a single point of failure and enhance the resilience of your application against potential outages or failures in a single AZ. This approach provides redundancy and improves overall system reliability.

countermeasure.name: Enable VPC flow logs
countermeasure.desc: Implement VPC flow logs to capture information about the IP traffic going to and from network interfaces within your VPC. This log data can help you monitor network traffic, identify potential security threats, diagnose network issues, and ensure compliance with regulatory requirements. To enable VPC Flow Logs, navigate to the VPC section in the AWS Management Console, select your VPC, and create a new Flow Log, specifying the destination for the log data, such as Amazon CloudWatch Logs or an S3 bucket. Regularly review and analyze these logs for abnormal traffic patterns and security incidents.

This tool helps you analyze your network configurations and detect access paths that deviate from your security policies. To implement, navigate to the VPC section in the AWS Management Console, configure the Network Access Analyzer by defining the scope and criteria for access analysis, and run assessments regularly. Review findings to address any unintended access, ensuring robust network security.

Regularly update and monitor these rules to ensure they align with your security policies and threat landscape.

usecase.name: Denial of Service
usecase.desc: Denial of Service attacks aim to disrupt the availability of services or resources to legitimate users. Attackers overwhelm systems with excessive traffic or requests, causing them to become unresponsive or unavailable to users.

threat.name: Single point of failure
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

A Single Point of Failure (SPOF) refers to a critical component or node within a system whose failure can cause the entire system to stop functioning. In a cloud environment like Amazon VPS, this can result from configuring all resources within a single Availability Zone (AZ), leading to potential outages if that zone experiences issues.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Natural disasters affecting a specific AZ.
  • Technical failures such as power outages, network issues, or hardware malfunctions within the AZ.
  • Cyberattacks targeting the infrastructure of a specific AZ.

Impacts

  • Downtime and service disruptions.
  • Loss of availability for applications and services.
  • Potential data loss or corruption.
  • Financial losses due to service outages and recovery costs.
  • Reputational damage due to service unreliability.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Natural Disaster: A severe storm impacts the data center in a single AZ, causing all services hosted in that zone to become unavailable.
  2. Technical Failure: A power outage in the data center leads to downtime for all resources configured solely in that AZ.
  3. Cyberattack: A targeted DDoS attack overwhelms the infrastructure of a single AZ, resulting in service disruption for all resources within that zone.

To mitigate this threat, it is recommended to distribute resources across multiple Availability Zones, ensuring redundancy and high availability.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1499 - Endpoint Denial of Service

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Unauthorized network access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unauthorized network access occurs when individuals or entities gain access to a network without permission, potentially leading to data breaches, service disruption, and exploitation of resources.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers using methods such as brute force or exploitation of vulnerabilities.
  • Internal malicious actors exploiting legitimate access.
  • Misconfigurations in security settings, such as overly permissive security groups or network ACLs.

Impacts

  • Data theft and loss of sensitive information.
  • Service disruptions and potential downtime.
  • Increased risk of further network and system exploitation.
  • Financial losses and reputational damage.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. External Attack: A hacker gains unauthorized access to an EC2 instance by exploiting a vulnerability in a web application and subsequently accessing the underlying network.
  2. Internal Misuse: An employee uses their legitimate access to explore unauthorized network segments, leading to potential data exfiltration.
  3. Misconfiguration: A misconfigured security group allows inbound traffic from any IP address, enabling an attacker to exploit services running within the VPC.

To mitigate this threat, enforce strict access controls using security groups and network ACLs, regularly review and update security configurations, and employ network monitoring tools to detect and respond to unauthorized access attempts promptly.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

threat.name: Insufficient monitoring
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Insufficient monitoring refers to the lack of adequate surveillance and tracking mechanisms to detect, log, and analyze activities within a system. In Amazon VPS, this can lead to undetected security incidents, compliance issues, and operational inefficiencies.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Hackers exploiting unmonitored vulnerabilities.
  • Internal malicious actors taking advantage of weak logging practices.
  • Unintended configuration changes going unnoticed.

Impacts

  • Delayed or missed detection of security breaches.
  • Increased risk of data theft or corruption.
  • Non-compliance with regulatory requirements.
  • Prolonged downtime and extended incident response times.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Data Breach: A hacker gains unauthorized access to a VPS due to a missed security patch, which goes unnoticed due to insufficient monitoring.
  2. Internal Threat: An employee with elevated privileges accesses sensitive data without proper logging, making it difficult to trace the action.
  3. Configuration Error: Misconfigurations in security groups or network ACLs are not detected, leading to potential exposure of resources.

To address this threat, it is crucial to implement comprehensive monitoring solutions like AWS CloudWatch and AWS CloudTrail, and to regularly review and analyze logs to identify and respond to potential security incidents promptly.

threat.name: Unintended network access
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unintended network access occurs when resources within a network are inadvertently exposed to unauthorized entities due to misconfigurations or oversight, leading to potential data breaches, unauthorized modifications, and service disruptions.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers exploiting exposed services.
  • Internal users accessing unintended resources due to misconfigured permissions.
  • Automated scripts or tools scanning for open ports and services.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Service disruptions and operational inefficiencies.
  • Increased risk of further exploitation and lateral movement within the network.
  • Financial and reputational damage due to data breaches and service outages.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Exposed Services: A database is unintentionally left accessible from the internet due to misconfigured security groups, allowing an attacker to access and exfiltrate sensitive data.
  2. Internal Access: An employee accesses confidential files stored in an improperly secured S3 bucket that should have been restricted.
  3. Automated Scans: An automated tool finds an open management port on an EC2 instance, which is then exploited to gain unauthorized access.

To mitigate this threat, regularly review and update security group rules, network ACLs, and use tools like AWS Network Access Analyzer to identify and rectify unintended network exposures.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.name: Unfiltered traffic
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Unfiltered traffic refers to network traffic that is not adequately controlled or monitored, allowing potentially harmful data to enter or exit the network unchecked. This can lead to security vulnerabilities, data breaches, and network inefficiencies in an Amazon VPS environment.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • External attackers sending malicious data packets.
  • Internal users inadvertently or deliberately bypassing security measures.
  • Misconfigured security groups and network ACLs allowing all traffic.

Impacts

  • Exposure to malware and other malicious content.
  • Data exfiltration or loss of sensitive information.
  • Network congestion and reduced performance.
  • Increased risk of further network exploitation.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Malware Infiltration: An attacker sends malicious traffic that goes unchecked into the network, infecting servers and spreading malware.
  2. Data Exfiltration: An internal user sends sensitive data out of the network due to lack of outbound traffic filtering.
  3. DoS Attack: Unfiltered inbound traffic leads to a Denial of Service attack, overwhelming the network and causing service outages.

To mitigate this threat, implement and regularly update security groups, network ACLs, and use AWS Network Firewall to filter and monitor inbound and outbound traffic.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Compromised IAM credentials
threat.desc:
General Threat Description

Compromised IAM (Identity and Access Management) credentials refer to instances where attackers gain unauthorized access to AWS resources by obtaining valid IAM credentials. This can lead to significant security breaches, unauthorized data access, and control over AWS services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors

  • Phishing attacks to trick users into revealing credentials.
  • Brute force attacks to guess passwords.
  • Exploitation of weak password policies.
  • Insider threats where employees misuse access privileges.

Impacts

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data and resources.
  • Potential data breaches and data loss.
  • Unauthorized modifications or deletions of resources.
  • Financial losses due to misuse of AWS services.
  • Reputational damage from security incidents.

Example Attack Scenarios

  1. Phishing Attack: An attacker sends a phishing email to an employee, tricking them into providing their IAM credentials, which are then used to access and extract data from S3 buckets.
  2. Brute Force Attack: An attacker uses automated tools to repeatedly attempt logins until they successfully guess a weak password, gaining unauthorized access to critical resources.
  3. Insider Threat: A disgruntled employee uses their IAM credentials to access sensitive information and leak it to external parties.

To mitigate this threat, enforce strong password policies, enable multi-factor authentication (MFA) for all IAM users, regularly rotate credentials, and monitor IAM activities using AWS CloudTrail and AWS Config for unusual access patterns.

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-287
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-287: Improper Authentication When an actor claims to have a given identity, the product does not prove or insufficiently proves that the claim is correct.

weakness.name: CWE-799
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-799: Improper Control of Interaction Frequency The product does not properly limit the number or frequency of interactions that it has with an actor, such as the number of incoming requests. This can allow the actor to perform actions more frequently than expected. The actor could be a human or an automated process such as a virus or bot. This could be used to cause a denial of service, compromise program logic (such as limiting humans to a single vote), or other consequences. For example, an authentication routine might not limit the number of times an attacker can guess a password. Or, a web site might conduct a poll but only expect humans to vote a maximum of once a day.

countermeasure.name: Connectors should be provided for integrating with identity providers (IdPs)
countermeasure.desc:
To ensure seamless integration with identity providers and strengthen authentication mechanisms for your API gateway, follow these detailed steps:

  1. Evaluate and Choose an Identity Provider (IdP): Begin by evaluating well-known IdPs such as Auth0, Okta, Google Identity Platform, or Azure Active Directory. Consider factors like compatibility with your API gateway, support for OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect, scalability, and security features.
  2. Configure the API Gateway: Update your API gateway to support the identity standards endorsed by your chosen IdP. This often involves configuring the gateway to handle OAuth 2.0 authorization flows such as authorization code, implicit, or client credentials.
    1. Access your API gateway management console.
    2. Navigate to the security settings or authentication section.
    3. Enable support for JWT tokens or SAML assertions if applicable.
  3. Set Up Communication with the IdP: Establish a connection between your API gateway and the IdP by registering your API gateway as a client application with the IdP. Ensure that you:
    1. Register redirect URIs that the IdP can use to send authorization responses back to your application.
    2. Configure client IDs and client secrets in a secure manner, using environment variables or a secure server setup.
  4. Implement Authentication Flows: Depending on the features offered by the IdP, implement appropriate authentication flows on your API gateway. For example, support the PKCE extension for OAuth 2.0 to enhance security in public applications.
    1. Ensure the API gateway can initiate the proper OAuth flow and handle redirects appropriately.
    2. Configure scopes, claims, and resource access policies as required by your applications.
  5. Test the Integration: Conduct thorough testing by simulating various authentication scenarios. Verify that access tokens are issued and validated correctly, and that user information is accurately retrieved if using OpenID Connect.
    1. Check logs for any authentication errors or misconfigurations.
    2. Use testing tools like Postman or Curl to simulate authentication requests.
  6. Monitor and Adjust: Once integration is live, continuously monitor authentication logs for any unusual activity or failures. Be prepared to adjust configurations based on changes to IdP features or security guidelines.

References

  • Google Identity Platform - Authenticating Users
  • Azure Active Directory - Authentication Scenarios

countermeasure.name: Distributed gateway deployments should have a token translation (exchange) service between gateways
countermeasure.desc:
To facilitate secure token exchange across distributed API gateways and prevent unauthorized access, the following steps should be taken:

  1. Implement OAuth 2.0 and OpenID Connect:
    • Set up OAuth 2.0 to handle secure token issuance and validation. This protocol will manage access according to user authentication and application privileges.
    • Incorporate OpenID Connect to provide an identity layer on top of OAuth 2.0 for user verification.
  2. Use JSON Web Tokens (JWT):
    • Configure the gateways to use JWTs as a compact, URL-safe means of representing claims to be transferred between two parties. This will enhance interoperability and speed of the token exchange.
    • Ensure all JWTs are signed and optionally encrypted. Use strong, up-to-date symmetric (HS256) or asymmetric (RS256) algorithms to secure token data.
  3. Secure Communication Channel:
    • Mandate TLS (Transport Layer Security) for all gateway communications. This will encrypt the data in transit, ensuring tokens cannot be intercepted by unauthorized parties.
  4. Token Expiration and Refresh:
    • Ensure that issued tokens have an expiration time to minimize the impact of a token being compromised.
    • Implement token refresh mechanisms to allow seamless renewal of tokens. Consider using refresh tokens with short expiration times for higher security.
  5. Distributed Trust and Key Management:
    • Establish a distributed trust model by designating key management infrastructure for token signing and validation across the gateways.
    • Implement automated key rotation policies and ensure that all nodes in the distributed gateway system are updated promptly to recognize new keys.
  6. Audit and Monitoring:
    • Integrate logging and auditing mechanisms to track token usage across the distributed gateways.
    • Use these logs to identify any unusual or unauthorized access patterns, which will help in timely detection and mitigation of security incidents.

Following these steps can help maintain the integrity, confidentiality, and availability of the API gateway system.

References

  • OAuth 2.0 Framework
  • OpenID Connect Introduction
  • Introduction to JSON Web Tokens
  • RFC 5246: The Transport Layer Security (TLS) Protocol
  • RFC 7523: JSON Web Token (JWT) Profile for OAuth 2.0 Client Authentication and Authorization Grants
  • Keycloak Server Administration Guide

standard.ref: SC-12 CRYPTOGRAPHIC KEY ESTABLISHMENT AND MANAGEMENT

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

countermeasure.name: Integrate the API gateway with an identity management application
countermeasure.desc:
To effectively provision credentials before activating the API and prevent unauthorized access, follow these detailed steps:

  1. Identify Credential Requirements:
    • Determine the type of authentication your API will support (e.g., OAuth 2.0, API Key, JWT).
    • Define user roles and permissions associated with different levels of access to the API.
  2. Generate Secure Credentials:
    • Use a reliable and secure method to generate API keys or tokens. Consider using libraries like JWT for JSON Web Tokens.
    • Apply strong cryptographic practices like using a secure random function for generating secrets.
  3. Establish Credential Distribution Mechanism:
    • Set up an access control mechanism that ensures only authorized individuals or systems can request and receive credentials.
    • Utilize secure channels such as TLS/SSL to transmit credentials during distribution.
  4. Configure API Gateway:
    • Segregate the API activation stage to ensure credentials are mandatory before any API consumption.
    • Implement infrastructure configuration that enforces credential verification for each API request.
    • Consider using API management platforms like AWS API Gateway or Google Cloud API Gateway to streamline this process.
  5. Test Credential Mechanisms:
    • Conduct thorough testing on how credentials interact with your API, ensuring that unauthorized access is denied.
    • Regularly perform security audits to check for vulnerabilities in the credential provisioning and verification process.
  6. Monitor Credential Usage:
    • Implement logging mechanisms to track the usage of credentials and analyze access patterns.
    • Set up alerts for suspicious behavior or potential credential compromises, using tools like Datadog or Elastic Security.

Following these steps will help ensure a robust credential provisioning strategy, enhancing the security of your API gateway and protecting against unauthorized access.

References

  • OAuth 2.0 Getting Started
  • JWT Introduction
  • AWS API Gateway
  • Google Cloud API Gateway
  • Datadog
  • Elastic Security

countermeasure.name: Securely channel all traffic information to a monitoring and/or analytics application
countermeasure.desc:
Step 1: Define Monitoring Objectives

Begin by establishing clear objectives for what the continuous monitoring aims to achieve. Identify critical assets, potential threats, and the types of anomalies that need detection. Consider strategic goals such as improving detection speed, reducing false positives, and ensuring comprehensive coverage across all API endpoints.

Step 2: Select Monitoring Tools and Technologies

Evaluate and select appropriate tools and technologies for monitoring API traffic. Popular solutions include intrusion detection/prevention systems, security information and event management (SIEM) solutions, and anomaly detection tools. Ensure that selected solutions can integrate smoothly with the existing API gateway infrastructure.

Consider tools like AWS CloudWatch, Azure Monitor, or Splunk which are highly capable in monitoring and analyzing API traffic effectively.

Step 3: Implement Traffic Logging and Analysis

Enable comprehensive logging of API requests and responses. Configure logs to capture metadata such as timestamps, source IP addresses, request URLs, HTTP methods, and response codes. Logs should be structured in a consistent format to facilitate easy analysis. Utilize log management solutions to collect, aggregate, and store logs securely for further examination.

Step 4: Develop Automated Alerting and Response Procedures

Create automated alerts for detected anomalies or potential security incidents. Configure the monitoring system to trigger alerts based on predefined thresholds and patterns. Develop response playbooks that dictate actions to be taken upon receiving alerts, ensuring a swift and organized response to incidents.

Consider integrating automated responses that can temporarily block malicious IPs or throttle suspicious activity to limit potential damage.

Step 5: Conduct Regular Threat Intelligence Update

Regularly update the monitoring system with the latest threat intelligence data. This includes integrating real-time threat feeds that provide updates on new vulnerabilities, emerging attack vectors, and other pertinent threat information. Collaborate with threat intelligence providers to enhance detection capabilities and adapt quickly to changing threat landscapes.

Step 6: Perform Continuous Improvement and Testing

Regularly test and refine the monitoring and response system. Conduct simulated attacks and penetration testing to evaluate the effectiveness of the implemented measures. Gather feedback and analytics to identify areas for improvement. Continuous refinement ensures that the system remains robust against evolving threats.

Step 7: Ensure Compliance and Reporting

Ensure that all monitoring and incident response activities comply with relevant regulations and standards, such as GDPR, HIPAA, or PCI-DSS. Develop comprehensive reporting mechanisms to document incidents and responses, which are valuable for audits and improving security posture over time.

References

  • AWS CloudWatch Documentation
  • Azure Monitor Documentation

countermeasure.name: The API gateway should have a connector to an artifact that can generate an access token for the client request
countermeasure.desc:
To enhance the security of the API gateway, it's crucial to implement a robust token generation mechanism. This process will ensure that only authorized clients can access secure resources. Here's a step-by-step guide to implement token generation for API client verification:

  • Choose a Token Standard:

Determine the type of token that fits your security requirements. Common choices are JSON Web Tokens (JWT), OAuth tokens, or custom tokens. For most modern applications, JWT is preferred due to its compact size and ease of use across platforms.

  • Set Up a Secure Token Generation Service:

Implement or integrate a token generation service. This service should handle the creation, signing, and expiration of tokens. When using JWT, consider a library like JWT.io for signing and verification across different programming languages.

  • Define Token Claims:

Decide on the necessary information (claims) the token should carry, such as issuer, subject, audience, and expiration. Ensure that these claims are minimal to protect against data leaks if a token is exposed.

  • Generate and Distribute Tokens:

Upon a successful authentication request, generate a token using your chosen library and send it securely to the client. Tokens should be sent via HTTPS to prevent interception.

  • Implement Token Validation:

At the API gateway, every incoming request should be checked for a valid token. Use your token service to validate its signature and claims. Reject requests with invalid or expired tokens.

  • Log and Monitor Token Activity:

Create logs for issuing, renewing, and rejecting tokens. Monitor these logs actively to detect any suspicious activities that could indicate an attempt to breach security.

  • Plan for Token Revocation:

Implement a mechanism to revoke tokens before their natural expiration if a security threat is detected or if a client logs out. Blacklist or short-lived token approaches can be beneficial.

Security Considerations:

  • Ensure your signing keys are securely stored, possibly using a hardware security module or a service like AWS KMS.
  • Use strong, commonly-accepted algorithms for signing tokens, such as RS256.
  • Regularly audit the token handling procedures for vulnerabilities.

References

  • OAuth 2.0 Authorization Framework
  • Introduction to JSON Web Tokens
  • Secure your Java APIs with JWT
  • Learn About JSON Web Tokens
  • RFC 7519: JSON Web Token (JWT)

standard.ref: PR.AC-1: Identities and credentials are issued, managed, verified, revoked, and audited for authorized devices, users and processes

PR.AC-7: Users, devices, and other assets are authenticated (e.g., single-factor, multi-factor) commensurate with the risk of the transaction (e.g., individuals' security and privacy risks and other organizational risks)

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Authentication bypass
threat.desc:
General threat description
An attack scenario in which malicious actors find ways to circumvent the authentication mechanisms, leading to unapproved access to API functionalities.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Attackers may exploit vulnerabilities in the authentication process or use stolen credentials to gain access without proper authorization.
Impacts
Such actions can result in unauthorized data access, data breaches, or service misuse, compromising both security and privacy.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker could intercept unencrypted credentials or leverage a brute-force attack to bypass login controls, gaining entry to sensitive API endpoints without detection.

usecase.name: Repudiation
usecase.desc: Repudiation involves denying an action or event that has taken place. In a security context, repudiation threats can occur when a user denies performing a specific action, such as denying sending a message or making a transaction.

threat.name: Exploitation of insufficient logging and monitoring
threat.desc:
General threat description
The absence of adequate logging and monitoring allows attackers to execute malicious actions without detection. This can lead to unauthorized access and potential data breaches with the exploitation remaining hidden from defenders.
Threat agents/Attack vectors
Cybercriminals may exploit this weakness by injecting malicious code into the API gateway or by initiating a series of unauthorized requests. Without proper monitoring, these activities can go unnoticed.
Impacts
This threat can lead to compromised systems, unauthorized data access, and potential data loss or manipulation. Moreover, it may result in delayed response to breaches and increased recovery costs.
Example Attack Scenarios
An attacker successfully bypasses authentication controls and gains access to sensitive data through the API gateway. Due to the absence of logging, the attacker maintains access over an extended period, exfiltrating data without triggering alerts.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1089 - Disabling Security Tools

weakness.name: CWE-285
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-285: Improper Authorization The product does not perform or incorrectly performs an authorization check when an actor attempts to access a resource or perform an action.

weakness.name: CWE-319
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-319: Cleartext Transmission of Sensitive Information The product transmits sensitive or security-critical data in cleartext in a communication channel that can be sniffed by unauthorized actors.

weakness.name: CWE-359
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-359: Exposure of Private Personal Information to an Unauthorized Actor The product does not properly prevent a person's private, personal information from being accessed by actors who either (1) are not explicitly authorized to access the information or (2) do not have the implicit consent of the person about whom the information is collected.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-693
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-693: Protection Mechanism Failure The product does not use or incorrectly uses a protection mechanism that provides sufficient defense against directed attacks against the product. This weakness covers three distinct situations. A "missing" protection mechanism occurs when the application does not define any mechanism against a certain class of attack. An "insufficient" protection mechanism might provide some defenses - for example, against the most common attacks - but it does not protect against everything that is intended. Finally, an "ignored" mechanism occurs when a mechanism is available and in active use within the product, but the developer has not applied it in some code path.

weakness.name: CWE-89
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-89: Improper Neutralization of Special Elements used in an SQL Command ('SQL Injection') The product constructs all or part of an SQL command using externally-influenced input from an upstream component, but it does not neutralize or incorrectly neutralizes special elements that could modify the intended SQL command when it is sent to a downstream component.

countermeasure.name: Enforce TLS encryption for all connections
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that every client-to-database and inter-node communication is encrypted using robust TLS protocols (e.g., TLS 1.2/1.3), thereby mitigating risks such as eavesdropping and man-in-the-middle attacks. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate TLS configuration into the deployment process and enforce these settings via centralized management tools, ensuring that all data exchanged across the network remains confidential and tamper-proof.

Implementation Steps:

Enable TLS Encryption:

  • Configure the Other Data Store to require TLS for all incoming and outgoing connections by setting the appropriate parameters in the configuration files.

Configure Secure Cipher Suites:

  • Enforce the use of modern TLS versions (TLS 1.2 or TLS 1.3) and disable deprecated protocols and weak cipher suites to maintain strong encryption standards.

Manage Certificates Securely:

  • Utilize a centralized certificate management system to issue, renew, and revoke TLS certificates, ensuring that all certificates are valid and up-to-date.

Monitor and Audit TLS Usage:

  • Regularly review connection logs and perform security audits to verify that TLS encryption is properly enforced across all connections and to identify any potential misconfigurations.

References:

  • OWASP Transport Layer Protection Cheat Sheet

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1041 - Encrypt Sensitive Information

countermeasure.name: Harden configuration and restrict network access
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that the Other Data Store is securely configured and that network access is strictly limited, reducing the system's exposure to potential attacks. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate secure configuration practices into their deployment processes and enforce robust network access controls through firewalls, security groups, or network ACLs. This approach minimizes vulnerabilities, limits the attack surface, and prevents unauthorized access.

Implementation Steps:

Harden Configuration:

  • Disable Unnecessary Services and Features: Remove or disable default settings, services, and features that are not required for your operations to reduce potential points of exploitation.
  • Apply Patches and Updates: Regularly update the database software and its underlying components to incorporate the latest security patches and best practices.
  • Secure Default Settings: Replace default credentials and modify out-of-the-box configurations to adhere to your organization's security policies.

Restrict Network Access:

  • Configure Firewalls and Security Groups: Limit access to the Other Data Store by defining rules that only allow traffic from trusted IP addresses and required ports.
  • Implement Network Segmentation: Place the database in a dedicated subnet or virtual network segment to isolate it from untrusted networks.
  • Monitor and Audit Access: Regularly review access logs and network traffic to detect and respond to unauthorized connection attempts or misconfigurations.

References:

  • NIST Special Publication 800-123: Guide to General Server Security

countermeasure.name: Implement secure backup procedures with encryption and access controls
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that all backup processes for the Other Data Store are secure by encrypting backup data and restricting access to authorized personnel. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate secure backup procedures into the deployment and operational processes to safeguard data against unauthorized access, theft, or accidental loss.

Implementation Steps:

Automate and Schedule Secure Backups:

  • Configure automated backup jobs to run at regular intervals, ensuring data is consistently backed up without manual intervention.
  • Test backups periodically to verify data integrity and the effectiveness of restore procedures.

Encrypt Backup Data:

  • Encrypt Data at Rest: Use strong encryption standards (e.g., AES-256) to secure backup files stored on disk or in cloud storage.
  • Encrypt Data in Transit: Ensure backup data is encrypted during transmission using secure protocols (e.g., TLS) to prevent interception.

Enforce Access Controls:

  • Restrict Access: Implement Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) to limit backup access to authorized personnel only.
  • Audit Logging: Maintain logs of all backup operations and access attempts for traceability and forensic analysis.

Monitor and Manage Backup Security:

  • Utilize centralized management tools to enforce encryption policies and access controls consistently across backup environments.
  • Regularly review and audit backup configurations and access logs to detect and remediate any security anomalies.

References:

  • NIST Special Publication 800-171

countermeasure.name: Implement strong authentication and role-based access control
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that only authenticated users with appropriate permissions can access the Other Data Store. By combining strong authentication measures with role-based access control (RBAC), developers and DevOps engineers can effectively minimize the risk of unauthorized access and potential data breaches.

Implementation Steps:

Implement Strong Authentication:

  • Enforce Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Require users to provide multiple forms of verification (e.g., password plus a one-time token) before granting access to the database.
  • Adopt Secure Authentication Protocols: Use industry-standard authentication protocols (e.g., OAuth 2.0, SAML, OpenID Connect) to securely manage user credentials.
  • Enforce Password Policies: Require strong, complex passwords and implement regular password updates to reduce the risk of compromise.

Establish Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):

  • Define User Roles and Permissions: Create clear roles (e.g., administrator, developer, auditor) and assign the minimum necessary permissions to each role based on the principle of least privilege.
  • Integrate with Centralized Identity Management: Utilize a centralized identity and access management (IAM) system to manage user accounts, roles, and permissions across environments.
  • Automate Role Assignment and Provisioning: Implement automation tools to streamline the assignment, modification, and revocation of roles, ensuring that access is promptly updated as roles change.

Monitor and Audit Access:

  • Log Authentication and Access Events: Capture and analyze logs for all authentication and access activities to identify suspicious behavior or potential breaches.
  • Perform Regular Audits: Periodically review role assignments and access logs to ensure compliance with the least privilege principle and to promptly address any anomalies.

References:

  • OWASP Authentication Cheat Sheet

standard.ref: Consumers Less Than Under 13 Years of Age (c)

countermeasure.name: Regularly update the database to the latest secure version
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that your database remains protected against known vulnerabilities by keeping it up-to-date with the latest security patches and software versions. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate a robust update management process into the deployment and operational workflows to ensure that the database software is regularly evaluated, tested, and upgraded as new versions become available.

Implementation Steps:

Monitor Vendor Releases:

  • Subscribe to vendor security advisories and release notes to stay informed about new patches and updates.

Test and Validate Updates:

  • Validate updates in a staging environment before deploying them to production to ensure compatibility and stability.

Automate the Update Process:

  • Use configuration management tools (e.g., Ansible, Puppet, Chef) to automate the patching process and enforce consistent update policies across environments.

Establish a Regular Update Schedule:

  • Define and adhere to a regular maintenance window for applying updates and patches, ensuring minimal disruption to operations.

Maintain Rollback Mechanisms:

  • Develop and test rollback procedures to quickly revert to a previous version in case an update introduces unexpected issues.

Monitor and Audit:

  • Log and review update activities regularly to ensure compliance with security policies and to identify any anomalies.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-40 Revision 3: Guide to Enterprise Patch Management Technologies

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Use parameterized queries and validate inputs
countermeasure.desc:
This control ensures that the Other Data Store is protected against injection attacks, such as SQL injection, by enforcing the use of parameterized queries and rigorous input validation. Developers and DevOps engineers should integrate these practices into their development workflows to ensure that user inputs are properly sanitized and handled as data rather than executable code.

Implementation Steps:

Use Parameterized Queries:

  • Implement Prepared Statements: Configure your database interactions to use prepared statements or parameterized queries, ensuring that user-supplied input is treated strictly as data.
  • Avoid String Concatenation: Do not construct SQL queries through string concatenation with user input, which can expose the system to injection attacks.

Validate Inputs:

  • Sanitize User Inputs: Validate and sanitize all incoming data against expected formats, lengths, and types using server-side validation techniques.
  • Apply Whitelisting: Use whitelisting approaches to allow only approved characters or patterns, thereby mitigating the risk of malicious input.

Test and Monitor:

  • Regular Code Reviews: Periodically review code to ensure adherence to safe query practices and input validation procedures.
  • Automate Security Testing: Integrate static and dynamic analysis tools to continuously assess and detect injection vulnerabilities.

References:

  • OWASP SQL Injection Prevention Cheat Sheet

standard.ref: PR.DS-6: Integrity checking mechanisms are used to verify software, firmware, and information integrity

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - M1026 - Privileged Account Management

usecase.name: Elevation of Privilege
usecase.desc: Elevation of privilege involves an attacker gaining higher levels of access or permissions than intended. By exploiting vulnerabilities, attackers can escalate their privileges within a system to perform unauthorized actions or access sensitive data.

threat.name: Attackers exploit outdated vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Failure to regularly update the Other Database leaves known vulnerabilities unpatched, enabling attackers to exploit these weaknesses and compromise system security.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, hacktivists, and nation-state actors.
  • Vectors: Automated scans to detect outdated software, use of publicly available exploits, and leveraging SQL injection or remote code execution techniques.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized data access or data breaches.
  • System downtime or service disruption.
  • Compromise of data integrity and potential lateral movement within the network.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker uses an automated tool to scan for the database running an outdated version, then deploys a known exploit to execute remote code.
  2. A hacker exploits a known SQL injection vulnerability in an outdated system to extract sensitive customer data.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1068 - Exploitation for Privilege Escalation

usecase.name: Information Disclosure
usecase.desc: Information disclosure occurs when sensitive data is exposed to unauthorized parties. This can include unauthorized access to confidential information, such as personal data, financial records, or intellectual property.

threat.name: Attackers exploit misconfigurations in database settings
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Misconfigured database settingssuch as default credentials, improper access controls, or unsecured network endpointscan leave the system vulnerable, allowing attackers to gain unauthorized access, manipulate data, or disrupt services.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, opportunistic hackers, and insider threats.
  • Vectors: Automated scans for default or weak configurations, brute force attacks on poorly secured accounts, and exploitation of unsecured network interfaces.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Data corruption or deletion.
  • Service disruptions and potential lateral movement within the network.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker identifies a database using default credentials and easily logs in to extract or alter data.
  2. A hacker exploits misconfigured network settings to bypass firewalls, gaining unauthorized administrative access to the database.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1046 - Network Service Discovery

threat.name: Attackers exfiltrate data due to insecure backup procedures
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Inadequate security measures in backup proceduressuch as lack of encryption and improper access controlscan expose sensitive data, allowing attackers to steal backup files and exfiltrate critical information.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, insider threats, and state-sponsored actors.
  • Vectors: Exploiting unsecured cloud storage, misconfigured backup systems, or weak access controls to gain unauthorized access to backup data.

Impacts:

  • Exposure of sensitive and confidential data.
  • Financial, legal, and reputational damage.
  • Non-compliance with regulatory requirements.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker scans for publicly accessible cloud storage buckets, discovers unencrypted backup files, and downloads sensitive customer data.
  2. An insider abuses lax access controls on backup repositories to copy and exfiltrate confidential business information.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1567 - Exfiltration Over Web Service

threat.name: Attackers intercept data due to unencrypted communications
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
When communications between clients and the Other Database occur without encryption, data transmitted over the network is exposed. This makes it susceptible to interception by attackers who can capture sensitive information in transit.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, hacktivists, and state-sponsored actors.
  • Vectors: Utilizing packet sniffing tools on unencrypted networks, executing man-in-the-middle (MITM) attacks, and exploiting unsecured Wi-Fi or legacy communication protocols.

Impacts:

  • Exposure of sensitive or confidential data.
  • Potential identity theft, financial loss, and privacy breaches.
  • Increased risk of subsequent attacks due to compromised credentials.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker intercepts unencrypted traffic on a public Wi-Fi network, capturing login credentials and personal data during a client-to-database transaction.
  2. A man-in-the-middle attack is executed on a system that uses unencrypted HTTP connections, allowing the attacker to modify or eavesdrop on critical communications.

usecase.name: Spoofing
usecase.desc: Spoofing involves an attacker pretending to be someone else by falsifying data or identity. This can include spoofing email addresses, IP addresses, or user identities to gain unauthorized access to systems or information.

threat.name: Attackers gain unauthorized access due to weak authentication
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
Weak authentication mechanisms, such as the absence of multi-factor authentication, simple passwords, or outdated protocols, can enable attackers to bypass security controls and gain unauthorized access to the database. This compromises the integrity and confidentiality of the data stored.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, opportunistic hackers, and insider threats.
  • Vectors: Brute-force attacks, credential stuffing, social engineering, and exploitation of default or easily guessable credentials.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive or confidential data.
  • Data manipulation, exfiltration, or deletion.
  • Increased risk of lateral movement within the network and subsequent security breaches.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker uses automated tools to perform a brute-force attack on a database account protected by a weak password, eventually gaining administrative access.
  2. A hacker leverages stolen credentials from a previous breach to access the database, exploiting the absence of multi-factor authentication to bypass security measures.

usecase.name: Tampering
usecase.desc: Tampering refers to unauthorized modification of data or systems. Attackers may alter data in transit or modify software components to introduce vulnerabilities or compromise the integrity of the system.

threat.name: Attackers exploit SQL injection vulnerabilities
threat.desc:
General Threat Description:
SQL injection vulnerabilities occur when user input is improperly sanitized, allowing attackers to inject malicious SQL code into queries. This can lead to unauthorized data access, data manipulation, or complete system compromise.

Threat Agents/Attack Vectors:

  • Agents: Cybercriminals, opportunistic hackers, and script kiddies.
  • Vectors: Exploiting unsanitized input fields in web applications, abusing vulnerable API endpoints, and leveraging automated tools to identify and attack SQL injection flaws.

Impacts:

  • Unauthorized access to sensitive data.
  • Data manipulation, deletion, or corruption.
  • Potential escalation of privileges and broader network compromise.

Example Attack Scenarios:

  1. An attacker inputs malicious SQL code into a web form that lacks proper sanitization, retrieving confidential customer records from the database.
  2. A hacker exploits a vulnerable API endpoint to inject SQL commands that alter or delete critical data, causing significant service disruption.

customField.value: ATT&CK Enterprise - T1190 - Exploit Public-Facing Application

weakness.name: CWE-1004
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-1004: Sensitive Cookie Without 'HttpOnly' Flag The product uses a cookie to store sensitive information, but the cookie is not marked with the HttpOnly flag. The HttpOnly flag directs compatible browsers to prevent client-side script from accessing cookies. Including the HttpOnly flag in the Set-Cookie HTTP response header helps mitigate the risk associated with Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) where an attacker's script code might attempt to read the contents of a cookie and exfiltrate information obtained. When set, browsers that support the flag will not reveal the contents of the cookie to a third party via client-side script executed via XSS.

weakness.name: CWE-284
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-284: Improper Access Control The product does not restrict or incorrectly restricts access to a resource from an unauthorized actor.

weakness.name: CWE-326
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-326: Inadequate Encryption Strength The product stores or transmits sensitive data using an encryption scheme that is theoretically sound, but is not strong enough for the level of protection required. A weak encryption scheme can be subjected to brute force attacks that have a reasonable chance of succeeding using current attack methods and resources.

weakness.name: CWE-400
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-400: Uncontrolled Resource Consumption The product does not properly control the allocation and maintenance of a limited resource, thereby enabling an actor to influence the amount of resources consumed, eventually leading to the exhaustion of available resources.

weakness.name: CWE-434
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-434: Unrestricted Upload of File with Dangerous Type The product allows the attacker to upload or transfer files of dangerous types that can be automatically processed within the product's environment.

weakness.name: CWE-539
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-539: Use of Persistent Cookies Containing Sensitive Information The web application uses persistent cookies, but the cookies contain sensitive information. Cookies are small bits of data that are sent by the web application but stored locally in the browser. This lets the application use the cookie to pass information between pages and store variable information. The web application controls what information is stored in a cookie and how it is used. Typical types of information stored in cookies are session identifiers, personalization and customization information, and in rare cases even usernames to enable automated logins. There are two different types of cookies: session cookies and persistent cookies. Session cookies just live in the browser's memory and are not stored anywhere, but persistent cookies are stored on the browser's hard drive. This can cause security and privacy issues depending on the information stored in the cookie and how it is accessed.

weakness.name: CWE-663
weakness.desc: CWE: CWE-663: Use of a Non-reentrant Function in a Concurrent Context The product calls a non-reentrant function in a concurrent context in which a competing code sequence (e.g. thread or signal handler) may have an opportunity to call the same function or otherwise influence its state.

countermeasure.name: Conduct frequent configuration reviews
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly review system and server configurations to ensure that security settings are properly implemented and sensitive data is not exposed. Conducting configuration reviews helps identify misconfigurations, weak access controls, and other vulnerabilities that could lead to unauthorized access or data leakage.

Implementation Steps:

Define Configuration Review Scope:

  • Include critical configurations such as access controls, encryption settings, user permissions, and network configurations in the review.
  • Ensure compliance with security best practices and regulatory requirements (e.g., GDPR, PCI DSS).

Review Access Controls:

  • Verify that only authorized users have access to sensitive data and critical systems.
  • Ensure that default credentials and unnecessary accounts are removed or disabled.

Check Data Protection Settings:

  • Ensure that sensitive data is encrypted both in transit (using TLS) and at rest (using strong encryption algorithms like AES).
  • Review file permissions to ensure that sensitive files are not accessible to unauthorized users.

Examine Security Policies and Rules:

  • Regularly audit security policies, firewall rules, and network configurations to ensure they are up to date and provide the necessary protection.
  • Verify that logging and monitoring systems are correctly configured to detect any suspicious activity.

Document and Act on Findings:

  • Document all findings from the configuration reviews and prioritize actions to address non-compliant configurations or identified vulnerabilities.
  • Implement changes and re-test configurations to ensure they align with security standards.

Schedule Regular Reviews:

  • Perform configuration reviews quarterly or after significant changes to the environment (e.g., updates, new deployments).
  • Use automated tools to assist with the review process, making it more efficient and thorough.

By conducting frequent configuration reviews, organizations can ensure that security settings are correct, minimizing the risk of exposure and ensuring that sensitive data remains protected.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-53: Security and Privacy Controls

countermeasure.name: Enforce role-based access controls and multi-factor authentication
countermeasure.desc:
Implement role-based access controls (RBAC), multi-factor authentication (MFA), and the principle of least privilege to minimize unauthorized access to internal systems and resources. By ensuring that only authorized personnel have access to necessary data and systems, these measures reduce the risk of accidental or intentional misuse of sensitive information and limit exposure to attacks.

Implementation Steps:

Configure Role-Based Access Control (RBAC):

  • Define roles within your organization and assign permissions based on job responsibilities. Ensure that each user has access only to the resources necessary for their role.
  • Regularly review and update roles to reflect any changes in job functions or responsibilities.

Implement Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA):

  • Require MFA for all users accessing critical systems or sensitive data. This ensures that even if credentials are compromised, unauthorized access is still prevented.
  • Use authentication methods like mobile apps, hardware tokens, or biometrics alongside passwords.

Enforce the Principle of Least Privilege:

  • Ensure that users, systems, and applications have the minimum level of access required to perform their tasks.
  • Review and adjust access levels periodically to ensure they remain aligned with users' current roles.

Audit and Review Access Logs:

  • Regularly audit access logs to ensure that access controls are being properly enforced and that no unauthorized access has occurred.
  • Implement alerts to notify administrators of suspicious or anomalous access attempts.

Educate and Train Users:

  • Provide ongoing training to users on secure access practices, including how to use MFA and why least privilege is important.
  • Educate users about the risks of privilege escalation and how to securely manage their credentials.

By enforcing these access control measures, developers and DevOps engineers can reduce the risk of unauthorized access and ensure that only the appropriate personnel can access sensitive resources.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-53: Access Control

countermeasure.name: Ensure server software is up-to-date with security patches
countermeasure.desc:
Regularly update all server software, including operating systems and applications, with the latest security patches. Keeping software up-to-date reduces the risk of exploitation due to known vulnerabilities. Establish a patch management process to ensure timely updates and minimize exposure to security threats.

Implementation Steps:

Establish Patch Management Process:

  • Develop a formal patch management policy that includes patch assessment, approval, and deployment procedures.
  • Prioritize patches based on their severity and impact on server security.

Automate Patching for Critical Systems:

  • Use automation tools to deploy critical patches as soon as they are available to minimize the window of vulnerability.
  • Ensure that automatic updates are enabled for operating systems and essential applications.

Test Patches in a Staging Environment:

  • Before applying patches to production systems, test them in a staging environment to ensure they do not cause system instability or conflicts with other software.

Regularly Review Security Bulletins:

  • Subscribe to security mailing lists, such as those from software vendors and organizations like CVE or NIST, to stay informed about the latest vulnerabilities and patches.
  • Monitor patch release cycles for both operating systems and third-party applications to apply patches promptly.

Track Patch Compliance:

  • Implement a monitoring system to track which systems have received the latest patches and generate compliance reports.
  • Perform regular audits to ensure that all critical systems are patched according to the defined policy.

Maintain Backup Before Applying Patches:

  • Ensure that a backup of the server and critical data is taken before applying patches, to facilitate recovery in case of issues.

By ensuring that all server software is regularly updated with the latest security patches, organizations can significantly reduce their exposure to security vulnerabilities.

References:

  • NIST SP 800-40: Guide to Enterprise Patch Management Technologies

standard.ref: Contract Requirements for Service Providers and Contractors (a)
ID.RA-1: Asset vulnerabilities are identified and documented
PR.IP-12: A vulnerability management plan is developed and implemented

countermeasure.name: Install and configure antivirus and IDS/IPS systems
countermeasure.desc:
Install and maintain antivirus software and intrusion detection/prevention systems (IDS/IPS) on internal servers to monitor and protect against malware attacks. These systems detect, prevent, and alert on malicious activities by analyzing server traffic and system behavior. Regularly update antivirus signatures and IDS/IPS rules to enhance their effectiveness in identifying new threats. Ensure that alerts are reviewed promptly to take immediate action against potential malware infections.

Implementation Steps:

Install Antivirus Software:

  • Deploy antivirus software on all internal servers to scan for and eliminate known malware.
  • Ensure that automatic updates for antivirus definitions are enabled to keep the system up-to-date.

Configure IDS/IPS:

  • Set up intrusion detection/prevention systems to monitor network traffic and server behavior for suspicious activities.
  • Regularly update IDS/IPS signatures and detection rules to stay ahead of emerging threats.

Configure Alerting and Logging:

  • Set up alerts for any detected malware or suspicious activities to notify system administrators immediately.
  • Ensure that detailed logs are maintained for all detected events to allow for post-incident analysis and troubleshooting.

Regular Updates and Patching:

  • Schedule routine updates for both antivirus and IDS/IPS software to ensure vulnerabilities are patched and signatures are up to date.
  • Perform periodic reviews of the effectiveness of the systems in place.

Test Effectiveness:

  • Run periodic tests and simulations to ensure that antivirus and IDS/IPS systems are identifying threats effectively and responding in real time.

By implementing antivirus and IDS/IPS systems, developers and DevOps engineers can minimize the risk of malware infections and ensure continuous monitoring of the internal server environment.

References:

  • Basic Intrusion Prevention System
